reviewText:
Things that might be deal breakers for you
These do not bother me, but they might bother you

-The trilogy will be expensive between DLC and 2 expansion. If you are completest you now know what you are getting yourself into.

-Additionally, the game has a new occupation mechanic. Basically, there are certain parts of the map which you cannot occupy and govern. In these regions your faction acts kind of like a hord. If you goal is to annex the world know that you cannot unmodded.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Changes from previous total war

-'Historical' battles are now part of the campaign instead of a seperate game mode. In past total wars I always felt that the game was missing a story to keep me going. At a certain point the all the battles just blended together. Having the quest battles in campaign helps in them down and adds importance to the campaign. Some of them feel a little odd in that there is no time limit or no conquences for failure.

-General and agent customization: The agents and generals are now much more customizable with abilities and names. I feel far more attached to my leaders and morn their deaths. They can also join in armies and fight in battles which is cool.

-Magic. The implications of magic are not as dramatic as one might think. The spells are interesting and need to be used strategically and do not feel spammy.  Ironicallly because the regular abilites are not limited by the magic pool it is the normal powers which feel spammy and poorly executed to me.

-Fly units: These units are extremely moble, however they still require planning and strategy. They can be just as effective as well timed shock cavalry or as ineffective as poorly managed cavalry. Many times the risk is getting this units isolated.

-Vanguard deployment: Some units can now deploy outside of the normal deployment zone making them excellent for scouting and ambushing.

-Regional occupation: You can no longer paint the world in your colors. Instead of occupying everything it give you a reason to sack and raze areas, which I have never done in any prior totalwar game.

-Seiges are focused on part of the city instead of the entire think. It's no better or worst than the older titles just different.

-Allies actually appear to be helpful durring wars

-Stability: For me the game seems very stable.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Problems which are still the same

-Battle AI has only minor improvements, but is still can only handle a narrow range of tactics from humans.
-Campaign diplomacy still feels arbitrary

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Railroading

Some people fear that campaign will be railroaded because of the defined starting possitions, quests and regional ocupation. However the campaign does not feel railroaded at all.

What does feel railroaded is the battle plans. The factions are so speciallized that you have limited tactical options. This is not to say that the game does not require battle planning, just that a faction has a prefered military doctrine that needs respected.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Warhammer is the perfect setting for a total war game. Warhammer has flashy units and lore in a violent universe which is at constant war. Even the poor diplomatic system kind of works for warhammer. Warhammer includes races which play very differently from each other.

Warhammer totalwar also is astep towards fixing one of my biggest issues with a total war game, battle context. The warhammer story arch and events add more context to battles.

If you are satisfied with past total wars you will be satisfied with this one too. If you are into warhammer, buy this it might be the greatest warhammer game for PC.

reviewText: If you're a fan of strategy and fantasy, you can't go wrong with this game. It feels smoother, and the battles are much more organic than previous Total War titles have been... no more unit bunching with troops magically sliding into place as they jockey for a position in the fights. While this game may be running on the same engine as Rome 2, you'd never know it. They've really put a lot of care and attention into crafting this title, and it shows. Don't listen to the negative reviews. If you do, you're going to be missing out on a great game. And for all of the people complaining about performance...I don't know what to say. I have experienced a smoother gaming experience with better framerates than I ever saw in Rome 2 or Attila, even months and years after their respective releases. In both of those games my framerate would consistently drop to down to the low twenties and even teens when zooming in to get a closer look at battles...especially during siege battles which were notorious for tanking FPS. In Warhammer, I can zoom in all day and still retain buttery smooth playability (all on graphical settings higher than what I ever set Rome 2 or Attila to). The game runs extraordinarily well, both on the battlefields and on the campaign map. In my opinion, the game has been very well optimized. And just so you have my specs for comparison, they are: Intel i5 4690k, Nvidia GTX 970, and 16 GB RAM. Anyhow, I hope that after reading this you do decide to pick up this title, because it is well worth your time. Happy gaming.

reviewText:
So.  I have now at the time of writing this put 9 hours in to Total War:Warhammer.
I will go over a short review from my personal experience with the game so far.

I would recommend the game mainly for its Battles, wether that be online in custom games or on the campaign, this is the strong point for the game. Battles are specticles of Huge armies, awesome spells and monstrous creatures, everything you could hope for in large scale fantasy battles.
Sieges, as much as the initial idea of corner/frontal seiges upset me, I now enjoy them (not as much as previous total war games though) They arn't sluugish they are much faster paced than previous games and I enjoy seeing the back drop of a fantastic City.

Bad point and its something that bugs me greatly, to which it nearly tilted the thumb up to the thumb down, that is the campaign. It has the depth of a puddle, building ques are tiny and generally the lands you leave behind are going to be fine for income and happiness. The only good part is that you get to go into huge battles.
The new agent mechanic is great, being able to send agents to do tasks and then bring them into your army works well, that being said Agents need (I stress need) a lot more actions outside of sitting in amries. Assasination, Block and destroy walls, Thats basically everything.

7/10 Needs better depth on the campaign, made up for with incredible battles (Just).

reviewText:
Are there bugs that pop up time to time? Yes. A unit of Slayers refuses to go through the gate I've blasted open and insists instead to slowly climb the ladder on the wall next to the gate. The Orcish Horde I'm facing decides to wait for me to bomb them into oblivion, kindly waiting for my Dwarven units to get bored. The Chaos Champion decides to run ahead of his army and die in a last samurai style suicide run against my Empire rifles. A battle turns into a last ditch, 1000+ unit bull rush of the main gate and the game stutters. Just a small subset of things that have happened to me.

Now, for the positive.

Assuming you play on Hard difficulty or above, which I've always found to be the only way you don't get bored in the end-game, the AI usually fights and maneuvers with a ruthlessness that can be shocking. Especially early game, when that one super stack of units you have is your lifeblood.

Speaking of your units, they are bursting with character. I've never loved a total war army like my battered Dwarven legion. The lore, Book of Grudges game mechanic, and flavor text really makes you feel that this army of Dwarves are a clan fighting for survival. Normally outnumbered, fighting monstrous creatures, I actually cheered when they pulled victory out of their hat. Hoping those little animated sprites went home and drank their world famous beer.

The campaign map is wonderfully varied, and does a great job of creating points of constant conflict. I've felt that entire wars have been fought over key settlement, only for the victor to be too weakened to push the advantage. Essentially creating a narrative that is just like the lore of Warhammer.

Monstrous units are a blast, and they don't feel like an instant win when you have them (I'm looking at you, Elephants from Rome 2). You are given a lot of ways to counter them, and are a fool if you don't account for them.

Magic feels like an epic addition, but not something you can use to force a victory. Buffing the right right unit at the right time, creating the best magical effect for the given situation, and having the dumb luck that lets that tower of fire move in the right direction to maim a tough unit, it always creates a great tactical decision. Side Note: creating zombies as the Vampire Counts is GREAT!

Chaos feels like it comes a little early to the game. While it's a great outside threat in the same vein as Attilla, I would like a little more time trying to conquer and unite my empire.

Your lords and named characters are a blast to have. Creating strong characters you grow attached to, who do not die of old age (which makes it terrible when they die in battle).

The quests for your Legendary Lords are... ok? While it's great to have these epic items of power, going to the far flung parts of the map with your Legendary Lord and his powerful army is a huge risk. And while you can teleport there for the battle, it costs 5000 currency, and that could be a lot depending on how your campaign is going.

I feel like I've rambled, so I'm going to end this review with this.
Buy the game. It runs well, it plays well, and it is truly a joy to play.

reviewText:
tl;dr I'd rate it a 5.5/10

Unfortunately CA really half-arsed Total Warhammer. At it's current state I cannot recommend it, at least not while it costs £40, simply because while it is fun to play, after several hours the tedium starts to build, and I find it hard to justify the money spent on this (At this early point, I'd like to stress. I'm sure the game will improve vastly, like Rome II and Attila have, but until then this will stay a negative review).

I'll be curious to see what price CA will charge for the Chaos Warriors DLC, because that potentially lifts the game from costing £40, to a grand £45.

Pros:

- A.I is actually semi-competent for once, which is unusual for a Total War title
- Spellcasters get a nice variety of spells
- The magic system is very easy to pick up
- The agent system is pretty nice, especially how you can deploy them as individual units on the battlefield
- The horrendous system of having to balance unrest in Rome II and Attila has been removed
-  Being able to customise Lords and Heroes is a great addition
- Is actually somewhat decently optimised, as I get a solid 30FPS on my potato, which got a nice 10FPS from Rome II at launch
- Units have weight, and cavalry once again packs a punch, which allows battle lines to move
- Mods have proper support now
- Factions have a nice amount of variety between them, although IMO the rosters are still slightly lacking

Cons:

- As far as I've seen, CA have skimped out on the unit animations a fair bit - I'm particularly disappointed with the animations of Crossbowmen, as they are one of several units without reloading animations
- Buffing spells have pretty terrible effects - just a fast moving 'airy' aura around them which disappears quickly. Personally I was hoping for something a bit more interesting, especially seeing how much content CA have skimped on
- Settlements? Never 'eard of 'em. In my 6 hours of play, and countless battles ingame, I've literally only seen one settlement, and that's only because whilst I was playing as the Empire some Skaelings besieged Altdorf. If a battle commences over a minor town/city, then the battefield will be a randomly generated map, no different to attacking or defending out in the countryside
- Being able to only assault one side of a settlement is disappointing, because it means that your tactics are the same more or less every single time, the only time it changing is when you get a new unit to play with
- The 6-4-4 building system that Rome II brought in which is absolutely infuriating, and should be done away with
- Trade is absolutely useless
- Diplomacy is absolutely useless, although fair enough it's a Warhammer game, but defensive and military alliances should at least be useful for something other than just raising opinion of you to the point you can confederate with the faction in question
- A lot of spells are unbalanced, although this will probably get patched soon
- A lot of range units are unbalanced although this will probably get patched soon
- CA shouldn't be relying on modders to add in essential parts of the game, like being able to occupy whatever settlement you'd like regardless of the culture (Human, Dwarf, Norsca, Greenskin etc). It's just more that they've not bothered with
- NO BLOOD FOR THE BLOOD GOD! (No blood or gore)
- Chaos Warriors is still cut content

A personal note is that I feel that the game feels a lot smaller in scale and depth than what was shown in trailers and videos by CA showing off the game (Which is to be expected I suppose)

I cannot see where CA have put all their resources for this game. I really, really, really hope it's not towards DLC. I miss the glory days of PC gaming, where expansion packs actually added hours and hours to the game, and lots of new content, and in the case of Rome I and Medieval II, adding hundreds of hours of gameplay. Those were the days where you got over a dozen fully fleshed out factions from the very start, instead of 4 + 1 integral faction you have to pay for.

All in all, Total Warhammer is by no means whatsoever a bad game, but it isn't fantastic either.

reviewText:
Product received for free

To preface this for transparency reasons, I've been given a press copy of Total War: Warhammer.

Total War: Warhammer has turned out to be a pretty spectacular game and will form a strong basis for future content expansions.

I've been a huge Warhammer Fantasy fan for over ten years. I've played Call of Warhammer for Medieval II and Mark of Chaos for PC. It's been awesome to see Creative Assembly provide a really quality game.

PROS:
1.) It feels very well optimized and the turns end quickly.
2.) The factions are defined and unique. There isn't a copy/paste feeling that
3.) The magic is varied and while it needs rebalancing for offensive magic, is a welcome addition.
4.) The aesthetic of the towns and campaign map is amazing. This is the new standard for future Total War titles.
5.) The AI feels more competent and logical. They attack when it's advantageous, they may broker for treaties and so forth.

CONS:
1.) There's still a need for an arcade option like in Rome I. The battles are very fast and almost overwhelming, especially with the addition of a new micro-management option (magic).
2.) I don't know yet how this is late game. But right now units will break and come back quite often. This makes the pacing of the battles feel frantic. The balance needs looking into for a more cohesive experience. I want to be able to watch the battles from time to time or have formations retained.
3.) I really did hope for a form of tabletop painter for units. I've always wanted customization in the vein of the Avatar mode in Shogun 2. The idea of changing their appearance and colors is pretty intrinsic to a Warhammer experience.

For my own personal score, I give it a 8/10.

An excellent Total War game with a Warhammer theme.
Pros:

- Great visuals
- Great sound design
- Varied units
- Good animations
- Battles are really fun and tactical
- The factions, albeit few, all play very differently

Mixed:
- There's gonna be a lot of DLC

Cons:
- Less in-depth on the strategic part than previous Total War games
- Regional occupation, you can only conquer lands from your nemesis faction. (Dwarves v Greenskins, Humans v Vampires. Chaos can only raze, which is fitting.)
- Sieges aren't as interesting as previous Total War games

Don't pay attention to the majority of negative reviews, they're about a small issue that can be fixed easily.
If you're still unsure about buying the game, there's tons of gameplay on YouTube for you to watch.

reviewText:
Product received for free

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9vYPk-VJeVU

Total War: Warhammer was developed by Creative Assembly and published by SEGA. Total War: Warhammer was released for Steam on Tuesday 24th May 2016. The price is £39.99/$59.99. A press review copy was provided for The Hidden Levels.

Coming into this game I had no idea about Warhammer and the last Total War game I played was back in 2004 with total war: rome, long before I had a reviewing mindset. This review will be from a more novice perspective as I only had four days to do everything before game launch. I dedicated three days to playing the game and the fourth to writing the review and video editing. I played Total War: Warhammer for a total of 29 hours playing through most of the Empire Campaign as Karl Franz and almost gained victory on easy difficulty before I had to peel myself away from the game reluctantly. I spent the other remaining hours checking out the other offline modes but unfortunately did not have time to test out the multiplayer.

Total War: Warhammer is a Fantasy RTS 4X Turn based tactical game in which you control one of four factions in campaign ranging from the Empire, Dwarfs, Greenskins and Vampire Counts in a bid to take over lands and gain control of the world. The game is completely set in the Warhammer Fantasy world and has a very engrossing campaign mode as well as several side modes such as quick battles and quest battles.

What I liked:Factions – There are four factions (five if you include Chaos Warriors) in which you can play as. You have the choice between 8 playable Characters ranging from Karl Franz to Mannfred von Carstein. After your choice of lord you can then hire lesser lords and use those to control in battles. I really loved the whole world and the mixture of factions all spread around. The diplomacy in the game is very fun too. The size of the world is absolutely enormous and can easily see you spending hours in scouring around the world attacking the Dwarfs to the east or Goblins to the south

Abundance of Achievements – In total there are a whopping 143 achievements! Some of the achievements are pretty difficult for instance “Win a campaign battle in which you are outnumbered 10-to-1” to the more easier  Have 1 level 10 Hero.”

Epic scale of battles – Zooming into the ongoing battles is really fun. You get to see all the action ongoing and it’s really impressive.  The one part of this game I really loved was Castle Sieges where you get to place archers on the wall and then zoom in and watch them fire down on the attackers. Attacking castles is also fun as you get to hire Siege towers and battering rams and watch them slowly approach the castle with nothing being able to stop them.

Detailed tutorial – Right from the get go the game offers to give you great advice from the starter characters. If that is not enough there is also extensive help by pressing F1 which opens a really big game guide which takes you through the changes and a lot more.

Mod Support – Luckily the game supports user modifications which will really help somewhat with the life of the game and to bring much more spice. At the time of writing this review there are already several really good player modifications including “Conquer Anywhere” – which allows you to take over any Factions settlements. Normally you are limited to taking control of only your own settlements.

Quick battles – I found this option really helpful for if you want to skip all the diplomacy and set up a quick custom battle on a battlefield between certain people. You can have up to 4v4. The game does start to get a little messy with so many troops on screen however.

What I disliked:The leader’s portraits – If you take a look around the world you suddenly realise a lot of the people in the same factions all look really similar. It would’ve been much better to have more customisation on the leaders visually to really give them more depth to the characters in the game.

Day 1 DLC Chaos Warriors  – I feel that the Day 1 DLC should’ve been part of the main game anyway. It seems a real cheap way to squeeze extra money from the consumers especially when you see them appear in campaign anyway. There’s an epic cut scene of them arriving and then you start hearing about their movements in the north with them razing villages and settlements. You question what is happening and can they really be that strong?
When they do reach you
date:
you then realise its serious. They are badass. Their troops and presence is enough to scare anybody on the field and everybody suddenly becomes best friends to take down the chaos. Only the toughest of people survive. I just feel with them added in the base game it would’ve felt like a more complete package. There are also Chaos Warriors achievements in the list.

Nord DLC? – There are also Nords at the north that seem very aggressive with everyone and waging war with everything they see. I’d imagine that they’d be added later as DLC or that they don’t let you choose them because it’s where the Chaos Warriors Spawn and you’d probably be obliterated by them very quickly.

Razed Settlements - Taking over razed settlements should take coins only as it says in the description when you go to build the settlement. When you build the settlement it takes away treasure instead of coins.

Lack of scenarios – The four scenarios on the game are good and last long
recommended: however I wish there was more of a custom scenario choice where you get to choose where you spawn or which faction you can use. The game really limits you to who you can be and what you can choose. More freedom and customisation would’ve been perfect. I would have also loved to been able to create a custom character and a faction. This would’ve given the game even more content and added that extra replay ability.\n\nFrustration – There was one point in the game where I spent time in the over world trying to chase enemies around. I spent all that time saving for epic tank army and then everyone would run away and as I turn back they would also go back to their original place frustrating me. It seems they know always the perfect places to stand to stop you from ever catching them in a mistake. Unless they are vampires of course
hoursPlayed:
they are dull enough to stand in your way.

Camera angles – In the game there are two camera angles with one being a top down bird's-eye view called the strategic view and the other view just being a normal view where you can zoom right up close to the troops and have a little height to it. I wish the camera could have more of an angled approach at the battlefield because I find myself on the tactical camera which is not close enough and the normal camera does not tilt to the correct angle.

Overall I really enjoyed Total War: Warhammer
voteText: my only qualms about it is lack of customisation and choices. I would’ve loved to have more control over who I played as and where I spawned. I really dislike the fact that Chaos Warriors was added as Day 1 DLC
helpfulPercent: when they could’ve easily been added to the base game. I would recommend this to most people as it really is a thrilling game with epic battles and much strategy involved.\n\nThe game has also made me interested in the whole Warhammer series and I will definitely spend time reading up and researching about Warhammer. Although there is an abundance of negative points on this review
votesHelpful: I feel the game is one to definitely pick up. Seeing huge medieval battles really is my fantasy.\n\nScore: Buy it now."

Within an hour of playtime the Dwarf-lords of the mountain holds had entered a new line in the great Book of Grudges and demanded that I correct an ancient wrong... the sacking of Bugman Brewery. reviewText:
Finally... After so long. After the pure horror that was Rome II. After the bogged down, sluggish Atilla. After DLC that was pointless and plainly, a rip off. After NO FAMILY TREE in Rome II (the blood boils...).

After all of this. Finally. Finally they have gone back to their roots of making a good game. Total War Warhammer is what I have longed for, for so long. The dreams are reality and it's done well.

The game is very well optimised out of the gate which is fantastic. The pace of battles of fast and furious, glorious.

Epic monsters wade through ranks of intrepid men, smashing and leaving bloody piles in their wakes. Heroes scream resolute cries as they dive headlong into opposing armies into their destinies. Finally we have a game that lives up to the Total War name.

HAIL SIGMAR. (Or Blood For the Blood God, if that's your style, or WAAAAAGHHHHHHH!!!)

reviewText:
The game itself is great fun.

Negatives, so far:
-The game occasionally crashes in the loading screen (seems to become more frequent the further I get into a campaign), especially annoying when it happens after a battle.
-Replay mode is pretty bad. There is no cinematic mode at all and no option to skip to a particular point in the battle (or if there is, I haven't found it).

Edit: Alright, it's actually not just occasionally anymore. At some point, savegames just become unusable because they constantly crash in the loading screen. I assume this is not universally the case, otherwise reviews would probably be a lot more negative but for me it happened in two seperate campaigns now. So yeah, sucks.

reviewText:
Been a big fan of the Total war series since the year 2000. I saw my cousin playing this game when I was only 12 years old and I was instantly hooked. When CA announced that they would make a fantasy themed Total war I had my doubts. I was not very familiar with the Warhammer universe, and with Total war I used to be a very conservative type of player. It had to be a historical era of mankind, otherwise it would suck big time. Boy was I wrong.... This, in my opinion, is a great Total war. I am not saying it is flawless or perfect, absolutely not, but it is a great Total war game.

I miss the proper naval battles that Napoleon and Rome 2 had, not having my ballista boats to be a bully on the ocean is a shame. The lack in 'premade' formations for your army is a small point aswell. did not use the option that often but it was nice to have just in case. But in all honesty I can't think of many more negatives right now with this new Total war.

The game so far has been a great experience, the units are great, well balanced and look awesome. There are dragons, giants, rocket shooting dwarves and a bunch more. Especially the hero's are cool, all come with their own specialties and a nice talent tree. The battles are intense and impressive, if you use a nice sound system with a good surround and a powerful subwoofer you will feel like a true commander in the middle of a battle. And last but not least, the global map looks great, its detailed and always changing. Vampire lords try to spread corruption and settlements have racial based looks, I like it.

My rig is a fairly decent i5-4440, gtx 960, 8GB of RAM and I installed the game on a samsung evo ssd. It run very well, never had a gamecrash and smooth framerate with high graphics on. I can even alt-tab during the game without any issues, might sound like a weird comment but many games tend to freak out if you put them in the background for a moment.

This game gets my insignificant seal of approval, i spent 50 euro's on it at a local retailer and I have been very satisfied with it. If you like strategy games and do not specifically hate fantasy genres and your pc is not a lemming trying to do calculations go for it.
voteText: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I was worried because I wasnt sure CA would do well outside the confines of historical strategy in the TW format.  After playing just a few hours, I can say this game is probably going to be my favorite Total War game ever.  Even though a few elements were dumbed down (town management for example), the addition of so many other Warhammer elements more than makes up for it.

The only downsides Ive noticed so far are the difficulty is much different than past games and magic is probably still a little too strong. Normal mode seems too easy, so if you are a TW veteran, you should consider starting and learning the game on hard difficulty.

Despite that, I will say this game is a major home run - and it is a huge shame that people are posting reviews based on day one technical issues (which are just par for the course with PC games - sorry).  The truth is, if you could run Atilla or Rome 2, then this game should run like butter on your computer (it does on mine).

If you are a fan of strategy games and/or fantasy settings, buy this game - buy it today. It's that simple.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: Let me start off by saying that I updated my rig earlier this year for Fallout 4 and the Witcher 3 releases (both of which I play on max settings at 60FPS+) and this game runs just fine. 5h in, no crash, no bug, no BS. People who are complaining of having issues running it or constant crashes need to update their GTX 200 series and their Pentium 2s. Read the specs first and either spend cash on your rig or get a PS4 and stop wasting everyone's time with your sad sob stories. Oh and update your graphic drivers duhh.

Now enough with the bad rig bashing...so far the game:
+Great graphics
+Fun gameplay and easy to get into
+I played Rome II less than 3h (then left it running overnight) and uninstalled it. This is nothing like it.
+Really feels like a Warhammer game. Its the fantasy world at its best.
+Great representation of armies and units from the original game.

Sure it might need a bit of tweaking and patches will fix things we poke holes through but it's a fun game and worth your time and money if you're a fan off Warhammer and the Total War series (Rome II excluded like me), then pick it up. Worst case scenario - return it for a refund.

Screw Rome II.

reviewText:
I have only played a few minutes and already have experienced some wonderful introductiosn to Warhammer Lore.  This is a very well done hybrid of Total War combined with teh Warhammer genre.  I can sincerely say that the old guard of Total war gaming will find this game comfortably familar while at teh same time Fantasy rpg elements are added without hindering the experience.

In all honesty, I have read through all the negative reviews.  One must approach these things objectively.  After first installation and running...I experienced a black screen....for about 45 seconds...then heard the thump of war drums.  My heart started beating as my knuckles whitened....would I fall on my own blade as others had and succumb to teh anxiety of Failure"....but before I crossed over the river Styx...the loading screen grasped at my hand and lead me across.

Not a single hiccup after that.  The negative reviews so far are not warranted.  I have not seen any that offer objective criticisms of the game.  My fellow warriors.  Patience is key....make sure all drivers are updated....let the game load and let it do it's thing.

I am sure some will have legitimate issues...that is the nature of game development and with such a wide variety of hardware
date: issues will happen.  Take note....most if not all of the modders and youtubers who bring us joy and info on have already had the game.  Many issues will be ironed out very quickly

reviewText:
UPDATE:
After 35 hours of campaign game play I can say this is the best and most enjoyable game I have ever played. Better than any other TW game IMHO as well.
TOTALLY ADDICTIVE.

The first time you see a Vampire Count Army approaching with their clouds of flying bats will give you the chills up your spine.

The GOOD:

Despite a shaky launch day, SEGA stayed on top of the issue and cleared it up fast.

The game is ADDICTIVE and IMHO better than any other TW Game, as not only is it Warhammer, but man oh man...when you zoom in for example and watch The Emperor or any of your favorite Lords/Heroes" fight up close and personal is truly and epic sight.

The campaign is fun and addictive
date:
so much so its teh only TW campaign that ever held my interest.

The UI and easy to understand and the hints and tutorial are great.

Sound and Graphics are great.

So many units and a great choice of factions.

The AI does a great job with varied tactics and keeps you challenged.


The BAD:

Shaky launch but SEGA stayed on top of it and got it fixed FAST.
Still some performance issues
recommended:
but minor.


The UGLY:

You can easily run out of graphics memory and when given the option to switch to RAM it gets slow.
Best bet is to be realistic and experiment with graphic settings.
Seems to be getting better.
The good news is that this issue only seems to affect the "turn animations" of teh faction badges...and the game does a good job of auto adjusting the graphics without any visible effect I could notice.
NO BIGGIE.

IN CONCLUSION:

If you are a Warhammer fan you MUST play this game!
Hours upon hours of campaign fun trying the different factions and I have not even gotten to MP yet."

reviewText:
I don't really do reviews, but i felt like this games deserves one.

As a big fan of total war, and i big fan of fantasy this game was a match made in heaven for me. i preordered thios game after seeing various streams i had to get this game. after seeing some reviews i was worried that the game may not work, but to my delight it worked perfectly, all i had to do was wait for everything to load for a while.

the game runs like a charm and the new additions brings the game to life. i feel attached to my generals as everyone has their own personality, skills and gear. Collecting gear is good fun, as it adds additional reward to defeating armies in battle. Also collecting gear through quest battles is a lovely addition as it adds a optional objective to the ongoing stuggle of your world. The quests battles are also matched to your current power, so you can get a nice even battle that will truly test your skills.

This combined with new units, a new world and much much more creates a fantastic experience for both veteran and new total war players.

reviewText:
I think that Games Workshop and the Total War team got together and decided that they could maximise profits in an epic crossover that would encourage fans of both games to get involved. Unfortunately the result is a game that isn't sure what it is supposed to be. I was unsure about this game since I first heard about it, especially considering the £40 price tag but of course in the end thought I would give it a go. You can see on my profile the time I have put into Total War games and that's not including the ones before Steam so please keep in mind that this review is from that perspective. Maybe for someone who is new to the series this game could be seen as a gateway to the other games but I think if you played Atilla or Rome 2 after this you would be overwhelmed at how different (and better) they are. IMHO this is basically a Total War lite game. Almost all the features that made Total War unique and different to other strategy games have been removed or completely changed in both the campaign and battle maps. I was shocked to find during my first battle that I can no longer even put my units into loose formation! Fortunately this mattered little since I quickly discovered the real time battles have now been turned into a successor to Battle for Middle Earth 2. The idea of deploying your army strategically before the battle and using the terrain is now a distant memory, replaced by a laughable mess as helicopters, dragons, eagles and ghosts zoom across the map, lightning bolts fall from the sky and incinerate your archers, giant trolls smash through your defensive lines and random vortexes appear to suck your carefully placed ambush into the depths of oblivion. Granted it all looks very pretty but that was never the point of Total War!

On the campaign map I also found this to be an issue, as you will often encounter armies that are less than half the size of yours, only to discover when you attack them that you cannot win as they have 2 units of monster trolls. So with only axemen and archers and one champion/spy to use how are you supposed to plan any kind of strategy? All you can do is spam build armies and try to overwhelm them with numbers (just like BFME2 or any other C&C style RTS). The campaign map does look very impressive and the music is absolutely amazing, but it seemed with this game that every time I noticed something good, something bad immediately came along to cancel it out. The developers seem to have gone to the trouble of including a huge number of factions as they usually do but this time none of them are playable and their culture and military are all identical. All the units are the same for every race, regardless of their faction.

Family trees are gone, champions/spies etc are gone replaced by a one size fits all hero unit, politics are gone and the standard diplomatic options you are left with feel like a pointless afterthought. Food production has been reduced to 0 importance as has trading with other factions and acquiring different resources, navies have been removed and the story is advanced by moving your army where the computer tells you in order to fight a famous battle" that apparently has nothing to do with anything else that is going on. For example
date: as the Dwarves I was told that to advance my story I needed to travel north to fight one such battle
recommended: so I sent my King and his army off to the flashing blue dot. When they arrived the battle was "Your forces have been ambushed by a great orc horde in the underground caverns
hoursPlayed: we must fend them off!" Well hang on a minute
voteText: if I hadn't got the message that I needed to go and fight the battle then I wouldn't even have been there so how can it be an ambush? Why am I fighting in the underground caverns when that isn't even where I was on the map? Why do any of these questions even matter when my own army was destroyed by the monster trolls yet again only to be saved by 2 platoons of Dwarf helicopters that have somehow managed to fly down a mineshaft(???).\n\nI must try and find some more good points so I suppose I could say they have really focused on the rpg element of developing your heroes this time which is great in principle
helpfulPercent: but yet again
votesHelpful: once you realise how simple the battles have become
votesTotal: having a general with a +15 charge bonus spell or melee defence buff just seems pointless. This means that instead of watching your heroes develop into a particular type of tactician and tailoring them to the units in your army as you could in Atilla
votesFunny: you are now simply picking random abilities from skill trees of literally hundreds of spells with no real tactical goal. The grand campaign has been removed
commentsCount: replaced by a vague story driven campaign for each faction in which you are only allowed to attack one race. Playing as the dwarves I am immediately informed that I can only declare war on the greenskins and my sole objective is to destroy them. Any thoughts of deviating from this objective are quickly removed on discovery that the map is designed with mountain passes in such a way that I have to follow a set route
column16: making tactical army movement or ambushing impossible. The towns themselves are now part of the map so the visible growth of the towns into cities from Attila and Rome has gone
column17: pretty much the whole board game feel of the campaign has been destroyed. There is little need to check your faction summary pages now as there is no longer any useful information there. I don't know if the developers felt that these elements wouldn't appeal to new players but it was a bad idea to take them out
column18: watching your families marry
column19: have children and evolve into great dynasties were some of the best parts!\n\nBattles for towns are now forced sally out and are all fought in the same generic bland landscapes with not a building in sight. Some of the big towns do look really good when you actually get to them but they are few and far between. All in all I think the creation of this game was driven more by financial motivation than by the desire to make a really great crossover. Finally it is also worth pointing out that the graphics are very impressive and without a doubt the best part of the game
column20: unfortunately this too is let down by the repetitive animations and the removal of 1 to 1 unit fight animations so that if you zoom in on what looks like an epic melee battle
column21:
you will basically be watching 50 units doing the same move over and over in the general direction of the enemy.

P.S
Charging another £6 for the Chaos faction (The MAIN ENEMY FACTION in the game who are even mentioned in the opening cinematic are DLC
column22: that's like having a Star Wars game where the Empire are DLC) when the game itself is already £40 is just incredibly insulting to all of us that have supported Total War since the first Shogun

reviewText:
I haven't had so much fun since medieval 2.  I bought most the games in between and to be honest I didn't like them anywhere near like Medieval 2 and Rome.  Rome 2 was very upsetting and still is to me, even with the bugs fixed its not too fun.

Figure I should probably elaborate for this game.  They mostly fixed collision as in when I watch human v human its no longer pathetic like before.  Seriously...this still makes me fairly upset every time I think about it since it took the devs this fricken long to fix that issue and I'n starting to feel really upset about it again now...  Anyway, there is some weridness with some of the different races fighting like dwarves vs orcs but its all forgivable and it tends to err on the fun side.

The stupid crap was taken out from city management.  I generally HATE when games streamline their features(looking at you dragon age and mass effect,) And you could say its been dumbed down but honestly none of the compexity in recent games was really needed.  Now you pick the buildings you want for the goals you want and you don't have to take the time to balance different negatives and positives and spend more time on positioning armies, battles and diplomacy.

That being said!  This game will be a adjustment for veterans.  If you decide to play on a higher level difficulty you can't just muck about with military power as the game limits your army building capacity somewhat compared to previous games.  Pick your strategic direction for your campaign and make sure that you are pals with everyone that is not your target.  Then build additional defenses on your backside just to be sure.

Another tip for veterans.  Devs took additional steps to countering your heavy infantry and heavy cavalry, you have been warned.  Branch out, diversify your army, or else.

I do have complaints, but I consiter them to be minor. One is that in your quick formations all the swordsmen are on the left side, and all spear are on the right.  Leaving me to switch my line up to balance it vs calavary every time.

reviewText: I've been a fan of the Total War franchise since the original Shogun and this release so far exceeds my expectations. If you've played any of the Total War titles before, this one is going be very familiar, with a few changes to fit the title into a fantasy world.\n\nThe game comes with four distinct race/factions, each one playing different than the rest. Although this could create a wide variety of race balance issues, so far it has not. I started my first game with the Empire ( human ) faction, proceeding into it about 75 turns before realizing strategically, I wasn't going in the right direction. reviewText:
I have to say that this game is fantastic. I'm a huge Total War fan, having played since the very first Shogun and almost always getting each new release. I'm not always impressed with CA's performance but more often than not they deliver fantastic entertainemnt with hours worth of fun.

As for this game, it's the perfect match-up for these two fantasy titles and you can really tell the time and effort that has gone in to making it look and feel exactly as it should. In some ways it's a typical TW game and in others it's completely new and exciting. The fantasy elemnt makes each battle and skirmish a visual treat and rather than auto-resolving some easy wins i played them just to see what it looked like. Magic has een balanced really well so that it matters without feeling too powerful and the fantasy units such as dragons and giants are lots of fun to use. I find that on my decent spec laptop I am able to run it without any issues and the loading times are lightning quick, which will amaze any of those who remember the loading times of Rome2 when it first appeared.

There are a few issues I' not keen on, such as the economy. It seems they have massively stripped back on economy building which means that even with plenty of territory you can'y field too many armies, this gets more and more difficult as the turns roll on and you expand more and more but hopefully someone will mod this if, like me, you find this limiting. I am finding some fram rate drops but I mostly play for the gameplay so this hasn't bothered me overly.

Overall I think this is a wonderful new addition to the TW series and a must have for all TW fans out there. I would advise getting this whilst the Chaos DLC is still free.

reviewText:
So far I have played this game for 6 hours after having owned it for 6 and a half. I have played a single campaign so far as the Empire and my review is based off of my experience so far. I may update this depending on how my experience goes.

TL:DR It's good but has some balance issues in my opinion. Unless you're a huge fan of the Warhammer and Total war series like me, chances are it's not worth £40/$60(?) that it costs. Wait a bit and pick it up on sale, unless you are able to spend £40 on a game with no issues.

First off, my system specs.
CPU: i7 4790k clocked at a standard 4Ghz
GPU:GTX 980
RAM: 16GB DDR3

Launch was standard and simple. No issues and was quick and smooth. Quickly checked options and found they had been set to Ultra so I decided to keep it at that and see how it goes. Upon choosing your faction and difficulty you can do a practice match and I did choose to do this. Game runs near perfectly and I haven't even updated my drivers for it. Good FPS, good shadows etc. Smooth and units  look much nicer than in previous games and appear to fight in a more individual manner which is nice.

Battles are too easy though. That's my one complaint.Almost no skill is required as long as you have some spear in the front, ranged units behind to support and cavalry to flank with you break the enemy almost instantly. It's ridiculously easy. The campaign itself though, with politics and diplomacy is a bit more complicated in some ways. Some things aren't  clearly explained so you end up having to figure it out and sometimes reloading to retry things. Irritating but not game breaking.

I haven't fought the dwarves yet and so far have only just engaged my first greenskins within the campaign, having spent my first 30-40 turns simply trying to reunite the empire. I'm not completely impressed with with the confederation option. So far I've failed to do force another faction to join me despite trying to be nice and also trying to force them with my military. Money is a lot easier to get flowing but my advice is that you need to make some serious land grabs quite quickly and to stay away from the global recruit options.

I'm going to try and play the Empire campaign a bit more and then I'll try some of the other factions though I am quite enjoying the Empire and have no real desire to play as the dwarves etc. Greatsword infantry OP af though Handgunners are underwhelming there is a mod which makes them do more damage, have a longer range and also have a longer reload. I would suggest downloading it.

Would I recommend this game? It's £40. That's a lot of money and I try to aim for the £1 per an hour of entertainment and I can see myself easily sinking a few hundred hours into this game. Yes, I would recommend, especially to Warhammer and Total war fans alike. If you aren't a Warhammer fan and are new to the total war series I would suggest either waiting for this to go on sale or to try an older Total War game first.

8/10. Has a few problems but I've already found mods that adjust for them and expect further modding will take this game to untold heights. It ticks most of the boxes for a nerd like me.

reviewText:
-Solid launch for me. My rig is mid-range at best and I still get pretty smooth FPS after a driver update, even in big battles and with magical effects up the whazoo. No CTDs or obvious bugs thus far either, albeit I get long load times but I'm not using an SSD.

-Looks good in motion. Animation work is pretty great across the board, especially the collision of heavy cavalry which is impactful. Large creatures are also superbly animated. Some of it might look too cartoony or blobbish, but it's Warhammer so it fits.

-Battle times are on the short side. Even a 20v25 unit Chaos vs Dwarves battle doesn't last 10 minutes. Which is annoying because you barely have time to enjoy the aforementioned animations, and basic units can die very, very quickly.

-AI is actually pretty competent, I have to say. It will use its cavalry decently, attempting to outflank you whenever possible and making a beeling for your siege weapons if you leave a gap in your formations. On the campaign map, it will attempt to raid you and attack weaker settlements if you let it, and will initiate diplomacy if it is in its interest.

-Factions feel and play very differently, so the somewhat smaller unit roster actually feels larger than in typical Total War games somehow. Some factions are still missing key TT units however (Knightly orders for Empire, Blood Knights for VC, Marks of the various gods for Chaos), albeit DLC might change that.

-Magic is weirdly balanced. Big bad vortex spell look flashy but are mostly useless since they deal little damage if they don't just wander off; meanwhile single-target spells can kill even mighty heroes like Grimgor in a few pinpoint casts that you cannot prevent, making the Lore of Death extremely powerful. I'm sure there are other balance issues too, but haven't played enough to really say. Dwarfs do seem extremely tough at the moment, only Chaos and their elite infantry seem to have a chance of breaking their lines.

All in all, a very fun experience thus far. I may revist this once I've played more.

reviewText:
By far one of the most inventive total war games to date. Total War: Warhammer has improved the series in several ways, but is missing some of the tactical options in prior games.

Pros:
-An incredible improvement on combat. Combat now is far more fast paced. No more do entire units watch the fight as the front line is the only part of the unit engaging. Charging is way more powerful and the impact of the units is impressive.

-The campaign unfolds an entire story before you. Each of your heroes and Lords hold so much value that it is horrifying when one is lost.

-A great take on hero power and magic.

-AMAZING CINEMATICS. The game looks amazing. From giant trolls throwing and smashing soldiers to comets falling onto the battlefield.

Cons:

-The financial system...

-Units are far more limited on abilities" (I.E shield wall

reviewText:
The most fun I've had in a Total War game in awhile. The improvements to the building of your cities is leaps and bounds better than anything Total War has to offer currently. Everything in the Tech-tree building is something I wish had hit home with past total war games, years ago. Its amazing.

Besides absolutley loving everything about Legendary Lords, I'm also loving everything about regular lords and the heroes you can recruit. Being able to spend the time to level them up and get them geared makes it almost heart breaking if you lose them.

And siege battles, being one of the most challenging aspects of the game, are a huge success in gameplay for my book. I do wish there was a perk or tech that you can get or research to help speed up the construction of siege equipment, if only buy a couple turns.

My only complaints are the models for the units, all they do is really swing at each other and there really isn't a true battle going on, something I've enjoyed watching since it was introduced back in Medieval 2. Also, a disappointing part is that when a Legendary Lord and the enemy Legendary Lord meet in combat, its not the legendary fight you'd expect it to be. Its just a you hit me
date: I hit you" slug fest thats boring and doesn't mean anything at all.\n\nOne last good thing for the review before I wrap this up
recommended: Co-Op multiplayer campaign is 1000x better then what it was in Rome2 or Attila. I felt in the past two games that co-op was just a dragging point of gameplay with 4-5 highlights that you can remember. With the help of a mod
hoursPlayed: TW:Warhammer Co-Op is amazing. Me and my friend have already put in 60 turns into our empire campaign today. And planning and helping eachother is what the game needed to keep me playing the coop for many weeks to come."

reviewText:
most polished on launch tw game I've played in years, here are a few positives/negatives. after 30 hours of vc legendary campaign before my gpu exploded.

* - the overworld campaign map is slightly simplified in terms of economic variety
*- no reload animation/climbing down siege walls animation
- lord v lord battles look a little wonky, perhaps paired animations for lord -v- lord would help out.
-no army painter/ability to colour yourself as a subfaction in singleplayer/multiplayer. would have been nice to represent my favourite blue humans (middenheim) in multiplayer. but there are mods at least already changing your skin colour to subfactions.

+ai- campaign map ai can and will be aggressive and actually respond to threats, on my campaign for example grimgor and his 2 stacks abandoned the siege of an estalian town to beeline towards my vampire armies I were mustering on the borders to go in and mop the scraps.
+- battle ai. enemy cavarly will disengage and continue to circle around looking for forces to hit in the back, forest battles against an aggressive enemy are genuinely unnnerving. ai is definately better but obviously still cheesable by 'sniping' or 'baiting' out defensive enemies.

+battle variety. its ♥♥♥♥ing fun. differing factions means I'm having a very different time all over. best time I've had in battles


I could keep going on, but after being bitter about this game for over a year I'm incredibly suprised with just how fun +varied it is.

buy it if you like total war OR warhammer and think you are a bad enough dude to take n the old world

reviewText:
Superb Total War game.

Although Total War: Warhammer sacrifices some mechanics from the previous titles, such as intricate politics, adjustable taxation, # of factions, it introduces remarkable new ones in TWW's unique factions and heroes. These factions are significantly different from each other, which promotes distinct strategies (ex. Chaos warriors cannot settle, VC lack missile units but can quickly resurrect units from the campaign map) and revitalizes the series by taking design risks that pay off. Customizing army traits and generals, now called lords, into super soldiers/mages feels much more impactful and rewarding than in Rome 2 and Attila. I had no prior experience with Warhammer content beforehand, yet I was still drawn into the fresh, dynamic gameplay of TWW.

The game does have a few flaws- AI agent spam can be overly obnoxious and unit balance is iffy at the moment (Dwarf Gyrocopters are significantly underpowered, while Chaos units are significantly stronger than other factions and can easily overwhelm the player after a few doom stacks). However, the AI in general is very good- definitely improved over Rome 2 and Attila. Multiplayer is lackluster- CA removed some customization options in custom battles present in R2 and Attila, and Multiplayer Campaign could still benefit from simultaneous turns/additional player support.

The game runs fine (better than either Rome 2 or Attila) and looks great. The upcoming DirectX12 patch will supposedly increase performance even more.

In conclusion, TW:W sacrifices some mechanics from previous modern TW games, but what is left feels very polished, unique, and enjoyable to play.

reviewText:
I have played the game at this point for about 20+ hours, almost exclusively with a friend of mine in online coop and I can safely say that despite the initial pre-order chaos ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t the game is very well polished, especially for a total war game. Anyone who played TW in the past and then came upon the beauty that was Shogun 2, that is how I am feeling right about now.

Perhaps the BEST part about this game, for us coop players, is that when the game desynchronizes instead of throwing you out it asks you and the other player if you want to attempt to resynchronize. Which was ♥♥♥♥ing mindblowing to us, in the past we would have been thrown out of our game (mid-turn even) and lose unnecessary progress in the process but NOT with this game! 10/10

Sieges feel very simplified, it is all about holding the walls and when defending you can feel that when they do breach through your gates it feels like your battle line (up top) is about to collapse because now you have to divert forces if you hadn't already.

The campaign feels very good too, the AI is finally competent enough to know when to back away from you instead of suiciding their armies and when they can they try to overwhelm you. And ♥♥♥♥ing finally when the AI is desperate to make peace with you after having you beat the living ♥♥♥♥ out of their big army they actually offer you large sums of money in return for peace, it feels like the AI has gained a humble" trait if you will.

The only downsides that I have noticed thus far is that you can't really play coop in vanilla
date: unless you want to play head-to-head. However I found it disappointing when playing as Vampire Counts and my friend as Dwarves that it was practically impossible for me to kill him because I couldn't settle any dwarven holds to act as forward base
recommended: not to mention the ♥♥♥♥ing lack-of-corruption attrition which forces you to go through their lands in raid stance which makes a trip from your capital
hoursPlayed: to theirs take about 7-8 turns. Meanwhile they can tunnel around you
voteText: attack your capital
helpfulPercent: raze it
votesHelpful: then return to their home and be still on time to defend from the attacking Vampire forces...\n\nI can't speak for any problems with the other factions
votesTotal: but I imagine playing as orcs (who can only conquer orcish or dwarven settlements) in a head-to-head against humans is equally as painful. There are ofcourse mods to fix this which brings me to raise the next big bonus: Steam workshop support! Must I say more?\n\nAnd a personal nitpick of mine
votesFunny: I absolutely dislike it that every unit (besides monsters and artillery I think) can spawn ladders infront of them
commentsCount: in the literal sense
column16: and climb a city's wall. I would have much more preferred to have seen ladders being a constructable siege item
column17: just like previous installments. Maybe a future mod will change this? Who knows.\n\nAll in all I think the game will be very enjoyable for total war players and perhaps abit more friendlier & welcoming to warhammer fans who are new to this style of game."

reviewText:
Despite an odd bug requiring me to play the game in offline mode first, the overall product is a fresh take on Total War. There are some things I have to relearn, new mechanics I have to decipher and a very welcome new RPG-like skill tree and levelling system (somewhat similar to Total War: Shogun 2).

As a history nerd, I'm not too overwhelmed by the fantasy lore, and frankly I haven't gotten the impression so far that I need to read up on it, although the information is available should I wish via an in-game wiki.

Also important is that it runs well enough for me, but obviously that may vary for others.


So far so good. I may update this as time goes on, but for now... Recommended.

reviewText: Fans have been waiting for a Total Game set in the Warhammer universe for a long time coming and Creative Assembly did not disappoint. This is the smoothest launch of a Total War game in a long time (maybe ever?). I have not experience any random crashes and performance is great. Magic and flying units are a great addition and add fun dynamics to the battles. Giant monsters also are fun to use and watch tear through normal units on the battlefield. I am torn on the removal of the village battles as sometimes they were fun but other times they were very annoying. I can understand why they were removed but I wish they kept it as an option. I'd give this game an 9.0/10 due to there being no Elvish races at launch.

reviewText: Hi the names Tom I was one of the guys on the begining of the end times mod for medieval 2(what ever thats worth)\nJust got a good 15 hours of playing in and I have to say the game is looking really good so far. My specs are an I3 3.4 750ti 2gb graphics card and 10gb ddr5 ram and as far as performance I get 60-30 fps on medium graphics settings but even at those setting it looks really good and only get frame rate drops during big battles. I hear Nvidia drivers need some work with total war warhammer so I expect the performace to get better as patches/drivers are released. The campaign is fun and challanging also the AI is better then it ever been in total war they can really give you a hard time in battles and also on the campaign. The new sieges are fun I did not think I would like them from what I saw but they are actually pretty fun I got to say. Overall the game is amazing I cant say enough how blown away I was by how well it ran and thats day 1. CA is famous for supporting there game years after release and patching to perfection but with such a good base to start with I can wait to see this game in a few months and after some patches. So if you are on the fence about buying the game I would say just go for it you wont regret it.

reviewText:
Like a dramatic game of Risk, in a sense. Very mountain bladey to the degree of controlling an army then waging battles with said army, the only difference being you don't outright control a main character, and engage in real time first person battles. However, it is a real time strategy none the less. This is the first game of Total War I have ever experienced, the reason being I do not like games that require turn based strategy, and I didn't realize the depth of micromanagement, as well as making the right choices, to create the right outcomes for your faction. A lot of trial and error, but very rewarding once you get the feel. Total Warhammer is something I can immerse myself in for many days to come. I have always liked Chaos, and this gives me a nice Chaotic fix. 10/10 would eat the world again.

EDIT 1.) It took me roughly 50-60 hours of gametime in order to understand the mechanics of the Chaos Warriors. Keep in mind this is my first Total War, so that attributes to the time spent. I didn't realize Chaos Marauders are to be used as fodder for the enemy, kind of like the Romans using lower level units then higher level as the battles progressed. I tried using high class high tier units as if I was playing Mount and Blade Warband, while focusing on building a mass of Huscarls to destroy the Sarranids... Chaos requires variety... And micro-managing.

EDIT 2.) It also took me aproximatley 64 hours to realize you can use multiple skill points on 1 skill...

reviewText:
The best Warhammer Fantasy Battles game we have on PC

And a great Total War game too. There are fewer races in here than what previous games in the series offered, however all of them are vastly different from each other in how they play with their army rosters offering a wider variety of troops.

The game is more hero centric this time, with army leaders being a tough to crack unit themselves, being able to carry various items improving their physical and magical side, as well as getting followers granting various bonuses either to an army in question itself or a region it is located in. There's a good choice of spells too, however they could've been more powerful to make a more noticable difference on the battlefield.

However there were some simplifications made compared to other games in TW series. Economics are much simpler now with a static background income together with income from cities, quests or your actions. Every infantry unit carries a ladder during sieges now, which makes them take less time and be slightly easier for the attacker.

Tactical AI is pretty good, properly countering your attacks, exploiting the terrain and flanking with its mobile units. On a strategic map AI is also considering its chances pretty well, trying to send its stacks into battle when it has chances to win. And because the commander is pretty tough - in a way it solves a problem with a dead or wounded leader demoralizing the troops right away.

It is also the first Total War game where I truly enjoy playing custom battles, since being able to create your own army out of Warhammer units and fight another Warhammer army is very enjoyable. And then there are also single scripted scenarios depicting battles from Warhammer lore which are great too.

This game is a much needed breath of fresh air for the TW series, get it now.

reviewText:
Awesome Fantasy Total War Game.

I have no previous experience with the minatures. Way too expensive and no friends ever had them.

This total war game is great! Each faction plays so differently from each other.

The Empire has standard units and some neat artillery. Their infantry and cavalry are armored and hit hard. They even have some magic.

The Vampire Counts are my favorite to play. I love all the neat cool monsters that they have. They have no ranged uints however. Also, their lreaders are very easily assassinated. I had over 15 Lords killed by enemy agents in one campaign. I love how they get to turn the map into Evil Lands of Death!

The Orks are a lot of fun. They get WAAAAAGGHHH! armies that add to their power. They tend to be more work as their armies must Raid to keep their 'fightiness' high. It is possible to raid in friendly territory although it makes the towns unhappy.

The Dwarves are good. Most of their earlier units are pretty much the same until you get the late game forces. They have no cavalry, which makes catching the missile units the AI builds a pain. However, they do have very good artillery.

Did not care for the Chaos faction. They are really hard to play. I prefer fighting them, but they have few armies to be honest.

All factions get research, which is really cool. Also, Lords and Heroes can level up and get cool new skills to use.

The map is great, with all sorts of twists and turns = what looks like a direct route is not.

However, I do unlike how the AI armies get to move and attack and move again so far. As the player you cannot move much after attacking but the AI gets to. It is currently impossible to catch a running AI army, they move much further than the player units.

Anyway, it is about time a FANTASY Totwl War was released. This is a good game. I hope it gets even better over time.

-Missing lots of awesome !features! / ideas from older TW's(*)
-*Setting up deffences/offensives when encamping/ambushing.
-Missing cinematics (for example: assassinations or corruptions!)
-*Missing mariage and family system.
-*Castles do not change in size when upgrading them on the campaign map.
-*Campaign cities do not grow in size.
-Small campaign map (I know they will make it bigger so it's not realy a con!)
-Missing races/factions to play as.
-Some Dwarve units seem poorly designed. (I dont know a lot about the fantasy WARHAMMER lore so I can't judge)
-Lack of units.
-*No formations.
-Missing buildings / designs.
-*No competitive multiplayer.
-*Missing Ranked games.
-*Poor multiplayer.
-Explosions/Explosing effects of artilery and catapults (Not including magic/spells or such things) look just copied from the older TW's and could've been better.
-*Missing special unit abilities such as WARCRY or shieldwalls.
-*Missing material usages.
-*Trading just gives you more income and materials are pretty useless now! Not used for anything. (Such as iron needed for weapon research or Stone for monument/special buildings and so on.)
-Missing Naval battles.
-Missing Generals.
-Low damage of magic, missiles, artilery and monsters (Which is okay for balancing but Id love a mod to increase the damage for atleast campaign battles.)
-Lack of voice acting.
-Allies are not working as allies. Do not declear war against your enemies and just ignore them/letting them pass/attack/raid/destroy you.
-Lacking political features such as gifting cities or threatening.
-(No trust system in politics) When breaking long alliances it literally does not affect anything. So you can just break any alliance without the AI losing trust in you :/ in the next 3 turns start another military alliance, after you burnt his towns. Makes no sense.

I probably missed some PROS and CONS but thats the main things I like/not like about the new TotalWar.

OVERALL: 8.9/10
I realy enjoy the game and I feel like its a big success after lots of bad critics towards the older TW's (Can't judge).
As a huge TotalWar fan im very proud to say this game is a GOD DAMN 8.9/10 FOR ME AND I LOVE IT!
Well done not ♥♥♥♥ing too much up CA! You're going to improve this game I feel it!
Keep updating and this will be revolutionary.

*Fairly reviewed since it has just been released and will be updated*

Thanks for reading and spending your time caring about my thoughts!
Cheers!

Every campaign in a nutshell:

Ai: Omfg stop killing me. Lets call peace.

Ai: Sure! (accept)

Ai: Want to help us battle against our enemies?
Me: Me: lol ofc, for a price. (demands 1500 gold)
Ai: Sure! (accept)

Ai: Hey! Lets have a trade agreement!
Me: lol ofc, for a price. (demands 1500 gold)
Ai: Sure! (accept)

Ai: You piece of ♥♥♥♥. I declare war on you!
Me: lol ofc, for a price. (demands 1500 gold)
Ai: Sure! (accept)

Ai: I need to walk my grandma 1 millimeter over to your land because she dropped her dentures. Can we pass?
Me: lol ofc, for a price (demands 1500 gold)
Ai: Sure! (accept)

Moral of the story: You can literally get money out of ANY scenario right now.

Ai: I have only one city left. Please, lets have a peace treaty and stop this bloodshed.
Me: lol ofc, for a price. (demands 1500 gold)
Ai: Sure! (accept)
Me: (Raids them again for even more money after treaty)


Anyways, the game is the most fun I've had with the Total War series in a while. As for content, there is a lot of it. But at the same time, the content gets repetitive. It's worth the full price depending on who you are to be honest.

I also feel like the music is a bit lacking compared to the older titles.

Overall, this game runs very well for me and is extremely fun.

reviewText:
The interface:  It's clunky.  Important Icons are scattered all over the place.  On some dialogs the dismissal button is a checkmark in the middle of the dialog, other times it's on the bottom right.  You have menus that jump up from buttons, but look just like buttons, menus that disappear before you have a chance to click the option you want

The AI:  The AI is essentially like playing turn based chess.  It will choose the softest spot to hit you every time.  It knows everything you do.  So if you start a siege half way across the map with your main force, don't be surprised when 10 different faction armies suddenly make their way through the fog of war and come take half of your territory.  It's really irritating when your allies then come retake the stuff you lost and you have to declare war on your allies to get your territories back.

Cut Scenes: The cut scenes were actually pretty decent

The Tutorial /  Intro:  It wasn't super bad, but the interface and how everything is laid out made it hard to follow.

General issues:  There's this really annoying issue where if you have a Hero (not to be confused with the Leader of your Army) merge in with your army it will somehow always be selected by itself at the beginning of the turn and you'll think you're moving your army when in reality you end up removing your Hero away from the army.  The AI will absolutely do everything it can to slay the Hero whom is now all by itself because its movement is higher than the Army and you won't be able to remerge them until next turn.  So I spent a lot of time clicking off my army, or pressing escape, and then re-selecting my army to move it.

I played multiple games on Normal, the AI is rediculous.  It will move just out of reach every turn.  It will exploit every mistake or mistep you make with surgical precision.  The only variability, or chance you might survive such a brutal, relentless AI, appears to be in the way it determines winners within battles.

Somehow the AI players get to obliterate your hero even if you lose a battle and are retreated a few spaces away.  It seemed like every time I lost a major fight with my main force my hero dies, whereas when they lost a major battle with their main force their hero always had a chance to flee far, far, away.

Otherwise, it's just battle chess with better graphics and units.  I would wait for the price to come down before purchasing this game, it's definitely not worth $59.99.

reviewText:
This is a quick first look into the game.

Completely new to this series but purchased due to the high praise. Running the game on my 3 year old toaster and took heed to the load warnings in the comments. After a 2-3 minute black screen wait upon starting the game, I was greeted by a high quality cinematic with solid voice acting. Interface is smooth and polished, however lags a bit when I try to open the public chat from the menu -- I'm assuming this is due to servers being a bit overloaded on launch as mentioned by the devs.

Loaded up a new campaign and I'm given a variety of choices of race and heroes reminenscent to Heroes of Might and Magic. Bits and pieces of lore that come up during load screens and selection moments made it feel immersive. Again, more cinematics follow and I am put into a real time battle right away with a voiced helper. My army consisted of a leader/hero and multiple unit types. It felt a little overwhelming at first with the rival army running at you, but do not worry since you're almost guaranteed to win the battle; just spend some time examining units and exploring the battlefield. The leader could provide buffs and spells and you are free to micromanage the multiple unit types in your army. The sound effects and voices set a great mood to the battles. It felt like a combination of Age of Empires and Romance of the Three Kingdoms. One thing that caught my attention was the spell menu, which, I didn't manage to figure out but it seems like your hero could utilize spells that could turn the tide of battles later on. There were previews of each spell and each one looked epic. I can't wait to try them out later. After battles you could also choose what to do with the captured enemy survivors and each choice provides a different bonus.

After the battle, the game teaches about managing your cities, which felt a bit like Civilization. You could upgrade your buildings that will provide bonuses to your army.

Overall, I'm pretty impressed with the level of detail, epic sounds and mix of various game mechanics and I'm only an hour into the game.

I'll update this review after progressing further, had to rush this review out to balance out all the peeps who gave a negative just because the game took a while to start up.
