reviewText:
I will compare this game with the other Total War games.
I have played Rome, Rome 2 and Medieval 2 total war.
I will divide this review in 5 sections: Settlements, Battles, Diplomacy, Campaign and DLCs.

Campaign
In this game, you aren't in Europe, Africa or Asia. You are in the world of Warhammer. That has some northern lands, forests and deserts. You play as one of the 4 main factions (5 in you get the DLC): Empire, Dwarves, Orks, Vampires and Chaos (DLC).
As you progress through the campaign, you can covince other factions of the same race to join you, gaining all of their cities and armies. You can also conquer them. However, you cannot occupy settlements of a different race,
After you grow strong enough, an evil force will come from the north and their influence can be felt in the entire world. That force is Chaos. They cannot occupy cities, only destroy them. Spoiler for the Warhammer books:  Chaos is the confirmed winner, as seen in the books. They destroy the world.

Diplomacy
The diplomatic options are the same as in Rome 2 Total War. You don't need an agent to travel to someone to start diplomacy. You can do this through the diplomacy menu. You can tell your allies where to attack. When Chaos invades, all factions have a diplomatic bonus, which makes you ally with the whole world to fight Chaos.

Settlements
The public order system has been greatly simplified. Buildings, technologies, commandments (editcts) and agents increase public order, while recent raids and enemy agents decrease public order. Instead of religion of culture, we now have corruption (vampiric and chaos). Playing as the Vampires means you need Vampiric corruption for your people to be happy, while playing as any other faction means you need to avoid corruption. If you have a lot of chaos corruption in a city, a chaos army will appear and rebel against you. The same goes for vampire coruption. You can lower the corruption with technologies, agents, characters and buildings.

Battles
Combat was greatly changed. There is no naval combat anymore (only autoresolve) and you can use spells if you have the right skills. There is no dynamic weather or time of day anymore. You can wait before the battle to get better winds of magic (spells recharge faster if there is more wind). You can equip your characters with weapons and armor and other buffs. You can give banners to your troops. You also have special quests battles you can start.

DLCs
There is only one DLC right now, the Chaos Warriors. You could have gotten them for free if you purchased the game in a week since it was released.
The chaos warriors are the major antagonists and are like the Mongols in Medieval 2 Total War.

Other:
You can rename everything in this game now: Generals, heroes, towns and even units. Customisation is greatly encouraged now since we also have a complex skill tree for each character. You can even roleplay!

I'll give this game a 9/10 because they removed naval battles and you only have 4 factions.

reviewText: Total War: Warhammer marks a major milestone for the franchise. Ever since Shogun: Total War launched over fifteen years ago, the series has tackled a variety of historical periods over the past two millennia, with a focus on units and scenarios that kept things firmly grounded in reality. In a turn of events that fundamentally redefines what Total War can be, this latest edition sees the core formula that mixes turn-based strategy with real-time battles married to the decades-old Warhammer fantasy universe. The result is a polished and highly functional strategy title that sacrifices some strategic depth for the novelty of seeing Orcs, wizards and vampires mingling with more traditional Total War units. Your interest in the Warhammer universe and what aspects of Total War games appeal to you will be the deciding factors in whether or not this is a must-play entry in the long running series.\n\nread full review [www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText:
This game has exceeded my expectations on release. It runs very smoothly and I haven't encountered any bugs within 40 hours of gameplay. I didn't pre-order and I got the Chaos DLC for free on the first week. This is a great example of companies listening to their fan-base as I wanted to see how the game turned out before purchasing.

Each race plays differently and each has a massive amount of character and charisma. The graphics and sound are lovingly crafted, nothing in this game has been skimped. Each of the 5 factions has fully fleshed out graphics, sound and story. It all gels into an immersive atmosphere which can suck you in for hours.

All in all this is a very well put together and polished game. It was clearly crafted by a team that loves warhammer and the result shows. Delaying the game has turned out to be for the best because it has been such a sweet and smooth release. A truly great game, worthy of soaking up endless hours. Recommended.

reviewText:
Like many other reviewers I have played the total war series since shogun and find this game to be a huge disappointment. Fundamentally, all the depth has gone from this game and the Warhammer varnish wears thin pretty quickly. There is little strategy either in the campaign map or battles. The AI is not very good (although a slight improvement on Rome 2) and there is actually a relatively small amount of content in this game (at least compared to previous titles). It would seem all the money in this game went on the ip and art (models, maps, animations etc ...) with very little gone into basic mechanics or thought as to how the game should play.

Pros
- Models look good
- Warhammer
- Orkz
- Game actually works on launch for a change

Cons
- Lack of gameplay or stategic diversity
- Simplfied campaign
- Only 5 playable factions
- Short replayability factor
- No semblance of balance between the factions

This game is still worth playing but I would recommend waiting till you can pick it up for half price or at least till the modders make the game remotely interesting.

reviewText:
I really enjoy RTS Games, however this is my first Total War exprience.  I'm used to a overhead view and micro managment of units, this was an entirely different exprience then I expected.  If you haven't played one of these before, it's going to take quite a bit of time and research to understand to move foward.  Once I invested a decent chunk of time on learning the system and what everything is I was able to expand and move forward and make progress.

There really isn't any story line or end of the progression,  while you can messure your success each day the value of it demishes rapidly and performing any action or battle becomes mondain and boring, that is to say for me anyway.

The game is quite polished and feels complete. The Tutorial needs a great deal of work for those that is not going to invest the required time as I did to get going (if you haven't played a Total war game).    But if you want a never ending game that you play for a few hours or a whole weekend for as long as you desire, this game has some great longivity. The Graphics, the races and terrain layout look excellent.

I'm a bit bais on the battles, I enjoy a good fight to the death. This, the battle is over in a short time and the enemy unit flees and get's away.  That takes a lot out of it for me.

If a demo isn't availible I watch quite a few youtube videos before making the investment. All the videos the players seeemd quite pleased and enjoyed the game, it's likely you could do the same. For me, It just doesn't do anything for me, I really had my heart set on it, I'd like to a find a new RTS that is more current and pleasing such as some of the graphics this game offers.

reviewText:
*Short hand review coming from someone who still loves Shogun2+FOTS, enjoyed Empire, felt burned on Rome2, skipped on Attila*

It was a sketchy first boot, it stalled on the Warhammer splash screen for about 30sec, but after that spooky moment it hasent done it again during additional bootups.  No technical faults my end, all graphics maxed, appears to be well optimized in my experience.
==========

For a Warhammer game it sure is skinny on the carnage, like by alot.  In Shogun2, theres blood, limb dismemberment and people rolling and withering on the ground who werent lucky for a quick death. FOTS brought Cannon fire that came down like the fists of an angry god and the fields become covered in a ghostly fog.  I would think a Warhammer game would have taken that noise up to 11.  Guess the blood god can go **** himself.

Combat animations feel really default and at times makes me think im watching a korean mmo than a TW game.  Lots of units hanging out and taking turns poking each other with the sharp end of the stick sort of deal, or ranged units landing shots but not seemingly having the effect they used to in previous TW games ive played...even if the targets were rocking shields, something about arrow units feeling more passive than impacting.


Overall id recommend it if your intrested in the Warhammer or high fantasy scene. It plays well, but it dosent seem to be gripping me personally all that well.

Will change my vote to a recommendation when I can blood for the blood god.

reviewText:
I certainly give this a mixed rating rather than yes or no, but because of the failure on things that have in the past been easy successes for CA it gets a no.

Single player campaign is flat out the best non-modded campaign we have gotten yet. Agents/heroes are amazing, magic is great, much of the changes made to the campaign map are fantastic and campaign map is actually difficult and dynamic and interesting. Diplomacy is worse and almost non existant though.

Props should be given to CA for their marketing team being honest and giving us real gameplay, they have made up for the Rome II debacle. DLC is already here to ♥♥♥♥ it all up of course, but as you probably know that is par for the course these days with Total War.

Game is beautiful, wonderfully optimized, and relatively bug free.

BUT gameplay is the least strategic and tactical that we have gotten yet. Battles are SHORT (10 minutes) rush battles, you don't even have time to proper flank or cycle charge or maneuver units, and that is not a micro issue, that is a simply the game ends too fast issue. The silver lining to that is it makes the AI seem more intelligent, since all it can do is rush and that is all a human can do these days as well.

Multiplayer is a joke and broken as hell. Why? Because 50% of the time the winning team simply spammed a single unit, either a hero or monster unit. There are no penalties or drawbacks to spams unlike in past total war games, those are desperately needed. And you thought fights against the AI lacked strategy.

Siege battles? Pah! They are a joke. sieges are a single wall (not even a fort you surround, just a single wall on a single side of a fort, of which you cannot actually enter), once the battle for the wall is over, the game is over. And every siege battle is, and has to be, a boring rush battle. And you would think that with such a narrower focus they could make more variety in the sieges, but nope, every siege in every location for every faction is identical.

Yes, mods will probably be to the rescue. But they are largely not here yet or still in infancy stages. When they are, I will update this.

reviewText:
I have just completed the long campaign in 56.3 hours, the map is tiny and the battles are very simplistic.
There are only 5 factions.
The battles require little to no strategy at all - everything ends up turning into a mosh pit either way.
It is fun when you first start but gets old fast.
I would highly reccomend NOT buying this game yet, and wait for a sale, as it is quite clear that they have locked off parts of the map, and held back on the other factions to sell as DLC.

Can't recommend this game in is current state. And I would suggest other people do the same so that these companys know they can't keep ripping us gamers off.

What I did find quite refreshing for a total war game however, is that all your held provinces dont randomly revolt en masse at some point through the playthrough.

reviewText:
As you can see, I only have some 45 hours played of this game so far, but I think I can make a safe judgement on the game based off of what I've played so far.

I played through an entire campaign with the dwarfs, and it had its moments, for sure. I enjoyed wiping out the greenskins, and I was genuinely frightened of chaos when they first appeared. I liked the gyrobombers, and nothing really came close to seeing an entire chaos warhound charge crumple under 4 squads of Irondrakes setting them on fire. The battles were genuinely fun, and it reminded me very much of the original table top game. So I enjoyed that bit, and it's ultimately what made me keep playing.

As the campaign wore on, though, and I realized how underwhelming chaos was, it came to a point where there was nothing left on the map but me, dwarves I hadn't assimilated yet, and the humans of Bretonnia and The Empire. My turns became nothing but cycling through the towns, managing what was being built, recruiting replacements for my 7 or 8 armies that were on the move, trying to make sure my two main quest-driven characters didn't get assassinated, and hitting next turn" a lot more then I really felt was necessary. After mopping up Barak Varr (leaving me with just 2 dwarf factions left to claim) I knew the game was pretty much a forgone conclusion
date: but I had to sit through it. It wasn't fun anymore
recommended: it was just tedious.\n\nSo I thought I'd try Chaos instead. Tried them out (got the expansion for free) and found that it was even more "next turn" waiting

reviewText:
The first impression of the game is good. There are no technical issues except for black screen flickering if you have Vsync enabled on Nvidia GPU's. The game runs well (i7 3770, GTX680 4GB, 18gb of ram).
The gameplay is the same, maybe simplified Total War gameplay you have known for ever.
However, in it's current state the game is in desperate need for rebalancing.
The AI just flat out cheats. You besiege, completely defeat and wipe out an army in a town, sack it, set up camp right next to it and within one turn the AI will have magically raised an entire army 2x as powerful as yours. That's cheating.
The mechanics are so unbalanced that it's impossible to play as Chaos. The mechanics of the faction make it impossible to succeed in battles. More than one horde next to each other are needed to defeat anyone and you can't because your hordes deplete each other faster than you can fight the enemy.

AVOID this game for at least 6-12 months. Then buy it on a steam sale.

reviewText:
I'm a passionate model painter and gamer as well as loving the Total War games since Rome. It's a perfect combination for me!

Factions behave so differently it is like playing a different game with each one, rather than just a re-skin with earlier games. Monsters like dragons and giants really add a lot to the battles to make them more exciting. More races will be added as DLC and I imagine, based on the current game, that will add a lot of replayability.

There are some things missing from previous games, like unit formations (wedges for cavalry!) Also, although the factions are very different from each other, there aren't that many in the core game... see DLC

There are a few bugs that need ironing out but when aren't there with a Total War game! If you are really into Warhammer and Total War then get it, although my advice is to give it a few months for it to be patched up.

reviewText:
I dont usually do reviews so I will keep this simple.  I haven't played much Total War but have experience with many similar sprite based games (Takeda mostly).  I am reviewing the campaign beacuse I have not had any chance to play multiplayer yet.
Positives (from a general perspective):
+Clean gameplay
+Different campaign mechanics for differnet races are lore friendly and diverse
+Not tooooo much frustration with unit pathfinding and commands
+Excellent siege gameplay
+Magic is a blast
+Runs great on my high end machine (60+fps/ultra/1080p)
+Looks FANTASTIC
+Awesome mods already in the workshop

Positives (from a Warhammer buff perspective):
+Great to finally have a professionally produced Warhammer Total War game, hopefully it continues to live up to the legacy of the Warhammer/Total War mods by adding more races quickly!
+Seeing the lore played out is a treat
+Loving the Chaos Undivided army
+Loving MOST of the magic effects

Negatives:
-Occasional unit pathfinding and command failure
-Lack of heavy siege weapon options
-Need more races soon (Tomb Kings and Skaven!!!)
-Would like to see better magical effects added to all spells (spells that say they turn the enemy to gold or set them on fire...should actually do that to the models they kill in the game...)
-Defense towers for sieges need to be reworked...

Pet Peves:
=Why is Blood dlc NOT included in the game at release?
=Chaos champion cant ride chaos dragon :-(
=Why cant I rotate or seriously zoom campaign map?

All in all 8.25/10...so far

reviewText: This is best totalwar game so far, and yes I do love historical setting too. Campaign is more fun than any TW games before because of quests, items, great skilltrees. And battles? I loved and played totalwar series from Rome:Totalwar spent lot of time with every single one of them and they were all improving slowly. But even in Rome 2 it sometimes happened that only 5-10 men from regiment actually fought and that was making me mad. After like 30 battles I do not notice it here, battle seems great and really fun not to mention game runs on ultra details with no high-end pc. I am playing battles against AI and people over net, which I avoided in TW games before (only played campaign, was not entertaining enough for me). But today I decided to write my first steam review because of last battle. I fought as dwarfs against greenskins and battle went bad. When my dwarven Lord was last man standing against wounded goblin shaman, three trolls, some spider riders and two half beaten spear gobbo regiments i thought its over... but somehow I wished for glorious death and fought them trying to avoid heavy hitting trolls biting myself against regiments of gobbos. Shaman was running around and supporting with some spells or abilities. I fought them for like next 7-8 MINUTES!!! slashing and killing one troll and many goblins until that scum Shaman came too close and died by my bloody AXE! And they all fled. This was best Close Victory ever from all games, not only TW games! Thank you CA! Take my money through DLCs I do not care, Hats down. Great job.

reviewText:
Almost completed the Greenskin Long Campaign.

The game, for the majority, is very simular to the other Total War series, but because of the fantasy IP some elements where changed to try to adjust to the new theme and address problems in the previous games. I felt the single campaign was very captivating. Nothing like trapping The Everchosen in Blackfire Pass with six armies ready for WAAAGH!

I ended up liking the fact I couldn't occupy human/undead settlements It actually helped. It encouraged me to branch out towards the north and west instead of turtle up. The greenskins can aquire a great amount of raiding wealth and fil that fightness bar up by letting humans occupy their land.

I enjoyed the army compositions of all the factions except Bretonnia. Understandable since its not a playable faction (yet)  but for multiplayer it could use CA to fill out some missing elements.

I am disappointed with the seige change. I understand the wanted to make seiges quick and simple ( and succeeded) but because of that the replayability of those battles are completely diminished because its just a rush to the walls. Defending corridors and city centers are completely superfluous. I also hoped the Karaks to have a great range of varity with tunnels and such to make thier sieges compeletly different.

The magic was visually stimulating but had minimal effect to not seem overpowered. I wish the lores where alittle more lorefriendly but what ever.

I hope to see Skaven, Highelves, Beastmen, Skeleton Kings in the future. Would be epic to see more Chaos Gods variation and I whisper of a dream of Ogre Kingdoms and Chaos Dwarves in the Darklands.

reviewText:
Hello everyone :) Today I will be tring to give a full honest review of TW: W

The Good
Performance:  First off let me say that my computer is good but it definetly isn't the best. So when I booted this up I expected mabye 40 FPS on high. What I got though was around 50-60 fps on ultra.

Campaign:  The campaign is great, you truly feel that every race is uniqe and they all play quite differently. As someone who usually played legendary on other TW games this one provided a new challenge to me and I had to bump it down to hard after my first few attempts as the greenskins.

Large Units/Magic:  These guys are amazing. It feels incredible to send in a giant spider as your line is crumbling or using your hero's flame spiral to destroy theirs. You can really feel they power of each spell, or eachstomp as they tear into the enemy.

Battle:  The battles in TW W absolutely stun me. From towering giants to shambling zombies I feel like the devs had a dream, and they fulfilled that dream. Everything feels so well balanced and the units look amazing.

Lords:  Having quests and skill trees is really great. It makes everything feel very open ended and allows large amounts of replayability.

The Bad
Bugs:  Playing through the game your going to find bugs. Lots of them. Most of these will be fixed within a few weeks but it must be included. So far I haven't found any gamebreaking bugs but that doesn't mean they aren't there.

Performance (Again):  As said previously I have great performance. However loads of people are saying that they get terrible FPS so make sure to look into whether or not your comp can run it.

Multiplayer  If its possible I think that the MP might have gotten worse since Attila. There are less options (Time of day, attacker direction, world map) and it crashes occasionally.

And The Misc  Arcade  Now, I'm not saying that this is a bad thing, but it must be included that the battles are much faster then in any previous TW game.

Economy  Since Attila all aspects like food/sanitation have been removed. Personally I hated the way Attila handled it but for those who like managing cities I just wanted to let you know.

Do you guys think I covered everything well? If not leave a comment and I will include it in the review.

reviewText:
I was playing as the undead counts, growing smart, raiding smart, killing smart.

I became friendlies with the orcs to the south-east of me which were wiping out the dwarves like nothing. This secured that flank. I had two regions fully controlled and fully upgraded, one for units the other for economy. I was making thousands a turn, while having access to all available units and fielding two, then three armies.

So, I'm growing, conquering, destroying. I attack the weak, the ones with only one or two settlements. I ignore the orcs which have a good chunk of the map, and an empire faction which also as a few cities and armies by me.

I make another faction a vessel and let them grow since I start and end wars before they can mobilize. At this point I have 3 full high tier armies, one down south trying to find easy prey to conquer, two in my region keeping me safe.

When bam, chaos comes along. I knew this would happen, but... I didn't realize how bad it would be. Chaos itself has four armies, each moving together, destroying everything. And the barbarian tribes are also moving hard, over a dozen armies between them.

They take my vessels second city, the one they got last turn, and four armies surround their capital the same turn. Over the next two turns I'm martialing my forces, pulling my third army back as fast as I can. My vessels armies get wiped out, but my banshee managed to destroy two full armies by successfully killing the lords leading them. Over the next few turns my vessel gets killed, and I can't help since my two armies would be fighting five armies from the barbarians, and four from chaos.

Suddenly the gods decide to favor me, and the ever chosen is left behind, just out of range of range of the other chaos armies so I pounce, my lord attacks him, he retreats. My second lord attacks him, and together my armies destroy his without losing a single group. Great right? It gets better, the empire, which are friendly with me, get a few confederations and vessels that Same turn, and just in my region have three armies fighting the barbarian tribes.

Next turn... Chaos reacts, two of their lords attack me, and I know if I retreat that will split my two armies apart. So, I fight. Two armies against two, mine have units going from nearly dead to a quarter health missing. I take out their artillery with my air units when their moving their armies to meet, fatal mistake for many of them. My calvalry engages theirs when I tried to flank. My armies are fighting their two lords, each of them flinging dozens of zombies and goals and skeletons a hit. But my armies were keeping their armies back at the same time, bam, the first enemy lord falls to the count leeching life from him in one massive spell. bam the second follows when my count slams into him with his undead flying horse, blade tearing through the massive birds skull. But what? Chaos refuses to give in! And so I battle and battle, doing everything I can to induce as much fear as I can, flanking to destroy moral even further. When their two giants come into the fray. My air units are harassing their units which were split apart, my two lords and my armies are fighting their giants with all they have. No more magic to use to heal or kill, low health on everything with the two giants only a quarter down. Enemy soldiers still coming, refusing to give up and retreat.

I have two air units left, out of the original five, which included an undead dragon, my lords are both nearly dead, my armies are nearky broken, and the enemy still has those damned Giants. It was a loss, my fate had been sealed when their monstrous units entered the fray to help the Giants. But it was a close call, and it was one that bought me just enough time to survive as a faction. I didn't even get besieged.

The empire, my friends, are pushing back the barbarian tribes, and chaos was nice enough to free up some settlements to my north, my fate is not at an end, if anything, this defeat will bring me future glory.

10/10, would die again.

reviewText:
As a big history buff the Total War Series has been one of my favourite franchises and I always am excited when a  new game is announced. Recently there have been many issues that have caused performance problems.

NOT SO in Total War Warhammer. For me, there have been no performance issues and NO CRASHES, working beautifully at 1440p even with no official SLI support* :D  and DX 12 next month.

This game also has a perfect addition of magic, monsters and flying units to add more layers to your experience. And you can rename just about anything and has day 1 mod support (even more next month)

I'm sure some fans of Total War that only like history titles may not enjoy this type of game (not sure why) but I feel this is a very solid game and produces a whole new kind  of challenge for the player. PLUS it's in the Warhammer Fanstasy world... its epic!!

TLDR: Great game, a combination of fantasy with the same Total War structure. Definately recommend!

reviewText:
This is, I think, the first game review I have ever posted on Steam. I am doing this because the developers truly deserve a pat on the back for this. For those of you who do not know Warhammer, the best comparible popular substitute would be Warcraft 3 for themes. This is an amazing adaptation of both Warhammer and Total War, and an improvement on Total War in seemingly every mechanic. This is a game that will addict you and make you care passionately about the faction you choose to play and every decision you make.

I have played Total War games since Shogun, the first one, and this is the first Total War game since being a child that has pulled me in and made me really feel like I am actually apart of this other world. I never played a single faction's Total War campaign as long as I have in this one. I am shocked at how much better the AI has performed, both in campaign strategy, and in the battles and I know that was not an easy accomplishment. When I am supposed to win, I still suffer decent casualties on normal difficulty (not saying I'm the best strategiest, but if I was favored in previous games it was a complete waste of time to fight because I'd lose 10% of my forces at most). I know this is the first Total War where auto-resolve has actually, frequently cost me fewer casualties!
I know the theme of this game might not be admired by some fans, but it is a personal favorite of mine. I love both Warhammer 40k stories and Warhammer Fantasy and this is an amazing adaptation for both games giving and taking everything I could possibly have imagined this company doing to deliver on this. I personally hope CA/SEGA keep this particular group going with DLCs and/or sequals/expansions.

Additional notes, the game has certain management features simplified because of the theme and I love that change for campaign about the most. You very quickly understand all the hows and whys of your faction, but yet will find yourself realizing there were much more effecient ways you could have run all of it and will want to play again.
Some very rare bugs that probably will get sorted out that caused my game to crash a couple times on the same battle. I unfortunately had to auto resolve it but luckily still won the battle (was trying to wound the everchosen's powerful army).
I'm on Ultra settings with a GTX 980 and it's running smooth, and temp is topping out at 81c (safe). I have a bit of an old harddrive and no SSD so I have some long load screens on this game, but don't normally experience large load times on other games so that's just warning for others, but I don't mind because you do not face many load screens.

This game was definitely worth the money. I am beyond satisfied and can't wait for additional content.

reviewText:
Do not be put pff by reviews written by people complaining about technical problems, they are either running the game on a potato or simply do not have the patience to google how to quicly solve forgettable issues.

Gameplay is fun, every faction has a different play style and feels unique, a much needed change fromt the copy paste factions in Attila and Rome.





The Game runs extremely smoothly on my PC, no lag nor game breaking frame rate drops nor any other issue really. I must hand it to CA, I did not have high expectations since the Roe 2 realease flop but they really outdeed themselves this time.














The game is fun, it looks great and runs fine, if you like total war style games and you like the warhammer setting (or fantasy in general) you will not regret getting this game.

reviewText:
Early review but great game so far.  Wanted to mainly comment on the game's performance and optimization thus far.  Running great and better than expected on my laptop of all things!  I was expecting 30 to 45 fps on high settings with a few settings at medium-ish.  However, I am getting solid 40 to 50 fps with Ultra settings with a couple of settings on high.  All of this at 1080.

Machine:
MSI GT72S 6QE Dominator Pro G
Windows 10
GTX 980M w/8 GB
i7 6820 HK 2.7 ghz
32 GB Ram

Again, expected okay fps on High settings, actually getting okay fps on Ultra.  This has held solid through moderately sized battles with moderate amounts of effects going on.  Only drops a bit during very intense and large battles.  Has yet to 'chug'.  GPU heat has maintained acceptable levels.

Gameplay is solid.  I prefer the UI over other Total War games.  Seems a bit more intuitive this time around.  The Warhammer setting is perfect for the Total War series.

Even this early, I would recommend.

I will update if I encounter any serious issues.

Edit: The above performance is with AC plugged in.  Would definitely have to crank down the settings if I was on battery only.

reviewText:
I want to tell you a story.  A story of a great Empire that spanned many settlements and forts, all united under one banner and quelled the petty squabbling of lesser nobles. Marching under this one banner they led mighty charges against the Orkish hordes, but there numbers were endless. Running low on money and reserves as the war had been at a stalemate for many many moons.... at this bleakest point a message was delivered to our lord. Chaos had arrived, we had heard rumblings of these hordes grouping in the Northern wastes. But that was many months ago now. Then like a blackness in the dead of night, chaos descended on the Empire. Towns  and settlements fell  along with armies of highly trained troops. Messages from Nule of rebellions. Even more disturbing was the fact that no orks had been seen in a  few weeks. At last reports came though of the war in the south... Chaos was there too... It had consumed almost every nation and all that was left were the brave men of the empire, holding the line against a foe that would not yield or relent. The war continues.... for now....



This game is so much fun. I have played the single player campaign now quite a few times as the different races and i can honestly say its the best experiance i have ever had with a total war game !

reviewText:
When I was a kid, Warhammer was the big thing. The small tabletop figures were abundant at my friend's house and I took a liking to them straight away. Total War does a fantastic job bringing those tiny figures to life.

While the game does stray from the past experiences, it brings a new aspect of Total War to the table (no pun intended). You control one of the game's factions, from the Human Empire, to the Chaos Warriors (badass). The similarities between the past games and this one are very similar. Diplomacy, trading, building your towns and armies. Where the similarities end are the battles.

Magic now plays a part and it is really fun to use, and can change the tide of battle instantly if used correctly. Heroic figures now play a HUGE part in your battles (Wizards, Witch Hunters, Captains, etc etc.) And their upgrades can be very useful towards giving your armies an edge.

The main factions you can choose from are: The Empire, The Greenskins (Orcs), The Vampire Counts, The Dwarfs, and the Chaos Warriors (which you can get if you buy it this week, instead of just pre-ordering it. GG Creative/Sega)

What I liked:

+ Similarities are abundant to previous games
+ Interesting quests and missions given during campaign
+ Agents (AKA: Heroes and Lords) play a bigger part compared to previous games
+ Very fun, nostalgic, well crafted with minimal bugs and glitches (so far)

What I disliked:

- Performance despite specs capable of running it maxed
- No gore, clunky animations for fighting
- Can be a bit hard to grasp for newcomers


This is an early impression, but I liked what I saw, and hope they support this game with the same amount of content (in a reasonable price range for the love of ♥♥♥♥!)

I was concerned about the limited conquest model but there is a mod to change this.  I played the first campaign without the mod and though I still do not understand why they limited the conquest it just meant I left a swath of raze settlements in my wake.   So in the end playing with or without the mod does not change much.

If you like total war games and or like Warhammer games I think you will enjoy this game very much.

reviewText: Preface: I haven't experienced any technical issue that others have been reporting, but even if I had, I don't think it would've been appropriate to downrate the game.\n\nWith that being said, this game appears to be very well optimized and is, overall, a great gaming experience! The main portion of the games plays like a combat-oriented version of Civ V, but the battles allow you to manually control your armies. Currently, there are some balance issues with the Auto-Resolve feature being under/overpowered depending on army compositions, and the enemy AI has a serious issue with spamming Agents to impede your progress. Overall, it's a great game, and I'd whole-heartly recommend it to something who loves strategy games and/or the Warhammer/40K universe.

reviewText: I've been playing Total War games since Shogun 1.  Total War: Warhammer is easily their best launch of a game. NO game or software is without issues it's just the nature of programming. However I've had no issues with crashes or hickups of any kind that interfere with playing. Gameplay its very solid, easier than attila as the developer stated but still challenging on higher difficulties. The only issues I see is it favors certain army comps way to much is autoresolve which may lead some to spam autoresolve, most of the fun is in fighting the battles. reviewText:
*Warning – Nvidia driver update 368.22 released on 05/23/2016 has been causing issues with frame rates with multiple users and Nvidia is currently working on a driver for Warhammer, though I am unsure when it will be released. If you use an older driver, that might help clear up some issues you might face with the game in terms of FPS. I will remove this warning once I know how the new driver will work for Warhammer.

First Impressions review, with about two hours in the game. To give you an idea as to what I am playing with and to what my FPS with everything set to high.

-Intel(R) Core(TM) I5-6600k @ 3.50GHz
-Nvidia Geoforce GTX 770 Superclocked at 4 gigs of VRAM
-8 Gigs of DDR5 -7.92 usuable
-DX 12
-Driver version – 368.22
-Resolution – 1920 x 1080, 60 GHz

Framerate is stable at 45-60 FPS on campaign map and 50 FPS on battlemap with full stacks; have yet to try more than one full stack. One thing I do want to make known is that if you remember my warning from earlier, I had an older driver and my FPS was stable at 55 fps on campaign but now fluctuates

Pros:
-Game runs great with superior optimization compared to titles in the past, and I have to admit that this game is probably the best launch in the series.

-Beautiful graphics

-64 bit supported now, so game used more RAM than previous games

-Strategic View was overhauled from Rome 2 and Attila giving you more information like road netwoks, faction opinion of you, etc.

-Straightforward and hero units are now more effective than before requiring the player to chose between having a melee/magical infinity Legendary Lord or specialize him in improving your army.

-Quest system is pretty impressive for first runaround, but after a while becomes repetitive. One good aspect though is that you can magically teleport your army to the area for a measly 5k gold.

-Factions play differently from one another. For example, the Empire can march a fair distance in open ground where as the Dwarves cannot; however, the Dwarves can use the underway to bypass large mountain ranges where as the Empire cannot.

Cons:

-No naval battles, though I usually autoresolved them in every game they were in except for Empire and Napoleon which IMHO were the best naval battles in the series until Shogun 2 Fall of the Samurai.

-No regional tax rate slider, so if you want to raise or lower taxes, you have to do it through the faction wide tax slider.

Mixed:

-Five factions which while seems like a con at first is actually pretty good seeing as they have an entirely different play style to other factions.

-Simplistic province control.

Here is my settings:

Anti-aliasing – MLAA
Texture filerting – Anisotropic 16x
Water detail – Ultra
Grass detail – Ultra
Terrain detail – Ultra
Building detail – Ultra
Unit size – Ultra
Porthole quality – 2d
Texture quality – Ultra
Shadow detail – Ultra
VFX detail – High
Tree detail – Medium
Unit detail – Ultra
Depth of field – off

Unlimited video memory - On
Proximity fading – On

I'll run an analysis on Ultra once a stable driver is released by Nvidia.

reviewText:
I'm pretty much a noobie when it comes to Total War games but I have to say this game has blown me away.

I played only a few hours of R2 (got bored very quickly) I didn't expect to be as gripped as I am with TW Warhammer. Having just completed the short campaign as the 'Vampires' I never felt bored or anything of that nature, the game kept me wanting to play more.
I really enjoy the different factions, they're all very unique and you really feel the power of the different lords and heros in battles. The ability to use magic adds a whole new element to the game and can really effect the outcome of a battle.
The game itself looks incredible, I play on ultra where you can really see all the finer details of the game, from the stained wood in the very depths of cities to the spilled blood on the floor, everything looks amazing.

Overall I'm really glad I brought the game and put in the hours to learn it. If you're thinking about buying the game then do it, it won't let you down (at least for me it didn't!).

10/10.

reviewText:
When I was a kid, Warhammer was the big thing. The small tabletop figures were abundant at my friend's house and I took a liking to them straight away. Total War does a fantastic job bringing those tiny figures to life.

While the game does stray from the past experiences, it brings a new aspect of Total War to the table (no pun intended). You control one of the game's factions, from the Human Empire, to the Chaos Warriors (badass). The similarities between the past games and this one are very similar. Diplomacy, trading, building your towns and armies. Where the similarities end are the battles.

Magic now plays a part and it is really fun to use, and can change the tide of battle instantly if used correctly. Heroic figures now play a HUGE part in your battles (Wizards, Witch Hunters, Captains, etc etc.) And their upgrades can be very useful towards giving your armies an edge.

The main factions you can choose from are: The Empire, The Greenskins (Orcs), The Vampire Counts, The Dwarfs, and the Chaos Warriors (which you can get if you buy it this week, instead of just pre-ordering it. GG Creative/Sega)

What I liked:

+ Similarities are abundant to previous games
+ Interesting quests and missions given during campaign
+ Agents (AKA: Heroes and Lords) play a bigger part compared to previous games
+ Very fun, nostalgic, well crafted with minimal bugs and glitches (so far)

What I disliked:

- Performance despite specs capable of running it maxed
- No gore, clunky animations for fighting
- Can be a bit hard to grasp for newcomers


This is an early impression, but I liked what I saw, and hope they support this game with the same amount of content (in a reasonable price range for the love of ♥♥♥♥!)

If you like total war games and or like Warhammer games I think you will enjoy this game very much.

reviewText:
Okay, I was going to wait a little while to write the review, but with all the negative reviews about people unable to play it; I figured I better chime in.

If you never played a Total War game let me give you a summary of what to expect. Total War games are a RTS game where you lead huge armies into battle. In campaigns you'll choose a faction and begin managing settlements/cities on an world map. Your goal is to take over the entire campaign map. You can build armies and send them off to fight in the wars you'll start. Now you can choose to auto-resolve the battles or you can command the armies yourself on the battle map. This is where the Total War series shine. On battle maps you'll send units groups to fight the enemy, and you are encourage to use tactics such as flanking, rear attacks, taking the high ground, and etc. to win the battle.

Now onto this latest entry into the franchise:

Total War: Warhammer is the first Total War game to break away from a historical setting and chose to go with a fantasy setting.  But the overall theme of the Total War campaigns is still the same formula; manage cities to get a good economy so that you can build huge armies to take over the campaign map. There are some unique changes depending on which faction you play as. Speaking of factions, this Total War game have got some of the least factions available for the player to use. With past Total War game having around 10 factions, this on only have 3 (4 if you get the preorder/week 1 purchase DLC). But with past Total War game, some of these factions was very similar to each other in play style but in there is none of that in this game. Each faction army rooster come with unique units and there no shared unit between them. So this lead to unique play style and army builds with each factions. At first I was on the fence with the limited number factions, but after seeing how different each are, I think in this case fewer is better.

On the campaign map, one big change Creative Assembly did was make it so that not every settlement on the map could be taken over. Dwarven and Orcish stronghold can't be occupied by the Empire and Vamp Count (and vice versa Orcs and Dwarves can't occupy human settlements). This is the first time Total War have disable the player from taking over the entire map. Now when I first heard this I was worried, especially since armies can take attrition damage as they travel through enemy territories. But you are able to sack them limited them useless to the enemy force them to send an army over there to rebuild the settlement, for a pretty huge fee. It also give you a good amount of loot for doing this. It’s an interesting new mechanic. I’m not saying it bad or good (I haven’t been in a campaign long enough for it make a huge impact on me).

Also another huge feature is magic and lords. Lords serve as general to your armies. Lords generally come in 2 categories: Warrior or Mage. Basically warrior types can take on whole unit with ease, and mage types can cast spells. Lords can tip the scale for fight into your favor. Since they are so powerful, you need to make a judgement of when it worth using them and when to keep them safe. On the campaign map you can level up your lords, and equip them with items and take them on quest to get more items and powerups to make the all the more fearsome on the battle map.

Magic basically is represented in the lower right corner of the battle map and will refill as the battle goes on. Using it at the right time can change the outcome of a fight. On the campaign map there is a feature known as the winds of magic. Basically if the winds are strong, then you’ll have a lot of magic to use on the battle map, but if they are week, you could have none.
I wish I could speak more on how well this game represent Warhammer, but I’ve never played Warhammer before. So I can’t speak on how well it keep to the lore and spirit of the franchise.

Now I’ve only been talking about single player because I haven’t played multiplayer yet. But from what I saw it fairly basic. You got your custom matches, quick battles, and co-op campaigns. With all this new stuff that they added to the single player campaign, I would have expected some new to the multiplayer.

All it all, I found this a refreshing new entry in the Total War franchise. I know many people had technical problems at launch, but the only problem I had was a slight drop in frames. Once I change the setting to high from ultra and I’ve haven’t had an issue since (my specs: i7-4790, GTX 960, 8GB RAM). It’s kind a funny this game run better on my machine than Total War: Rome 2. I’ve had a lot of fun with this game, and can’t wait to playing this some more, especially with all the free DLC that CA announced for this game.

reviewText: Read and don't waste your emperor's time with thumbs down, or I shall show no mercy on you nor your village, as it will burn under my army, its women and children given to the pleasures of my soldiers and then sold to slavery, and its men executed in front of the eyes of their families, then I am Emperor Karl Franz, and I do not tolerate thumbs down.\n\nThe game is as great as it can get. Your armies stand ready to fight, taunting the enemy, under a beautiful scenery of which you can use any part of it, to your advantage (or disadvantage). Send your infantry forward, have your cavalry hiding in a forest, engage your opponents outnumbered 1:3, and when they thought they won, that is when you send your cavalry around their whole army to charge into your enemies back. Watch them react in panic, as they throw down their banners, and flee the battlefield. Watch your infantry laugh at them running away in fear, as your mighty cavalry now charges into the enemies crossbow soldiers. As soon as those soldiers see your horse, they throw down their weapons and flee in panic. You, Lord Reader of this Review, under my guidance and under my command, you shall bring me the head of my enemies, and most importantly, you shall bring me the head of all the leaders of my enemies, as my hall is in dire need of their skulls that shall be turned into my personal drinking cups. Go out there and enjoy fighting against a great AI, face those unpredictable challenges, forge those alliances, squash those abominations, and enjoy being who you were born to be! No, not the emperor because that is me, but a lord commanding my armies.

reviewText:
Being a Games Workshop fan since childhood, I am so glad to say that this is the game I've always imagined and wished for.

when I bought Shadow of the Horned Rat, Dark Omen, Mark Of Chaos... They were fantastic games, each of them. But they weren't quite everything I wanted.

This is about as close as I could have hoped to get, I'm not saying this game is perfect and I'm sure there's more refinement and features to come.

But right now I feel like I'm 10 years old again and instead of rolling die and moving painstakingly painted models around a polystyrene and cardboard battlefield with nothing but my imagination to visualise the clash of steel and the devastating lightening cracks of spells gone awry, I have this.
And it couldn't have been closer to the pictures in my adolescent mind if I were actually crazy and the whole thing was a hallucination.

This isn't really a review, it's more of a love letter to the amazing people who worked on this game, Thanks guys.

reviewText:
THE EFFORT ROME 2 SHOULD HAVE HAD!!

Total War fan since Rome 1 (still my all time favorite). This game is incredible.

VOICE ACTING: Fantastic. Rome 2's voice acting was horrid, this is an absolute 180 degree turn. The intro speeches, battles and campaign map are superb.

MUSIC: BRING BACK JEFF VAN DYCK! That said I'm really enjoying the musical score of this game.

PERFORMANCE: GTX 970
8 GB ram
i5-4670K Oc'd to 4.0
Had a 55 unit battle, no slowdown on max graphics, minus V-sync and blur. Performance is outstanding.

ATMOSPHERE: Really sucks you in. Levelling up your hero's and lord's, magic abilities are great fun.

GRAPHICS: Awesome. Some people dislike the lack of 1v1 fights between units but I think it looks way better. Less blobbing, and charges look solid.

Sorry for the rushed review, but this is the first game in awhile that I really want to get back to playing. Buy it.

Game is running perfectly

GTX 770 with 2 GB VRAM

AMD 8320

Shadows off and a few more tweaks,VOILA.SOLID 60 FPS

Now to the review,this is so far the best TW game in my honest opinion.

Pros:
-AI is actually improved.It's IMPROVED A LOT.You get flanked a lot,campaing AI is not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ anymore.They actually move their armier to defend their cities from you.You have to either trick them,or pulverize them completely.

-Combat is improved.Battles lasting short is entirely subjective,so I'm not commenting on that.
Anyways,we are back to the medieval 2 style combat ! Units remain in formation unless they are devastated by cavalry,then their formation is broken and they can't reform IN COMBAT.That's a huge bonus.Flanking is actually possible now.

-Optimization is 4x better than Attila.While I can barely run attila at 40 fps with the same tweaks,I get solid 60 fps in TWW.

-Graphics are really good,even though I don't have shadows.Those unit models are awesome just to stare at.

-Cavalry charges IMPROVED IMMENSELY.They actually WRECK infantry.I even saw a unit fly 10 meters away from his friends.

-Legendary Lords are epic.They give you the I'm more powerful than the rest" feeling.Watching Kholek smash infantry around him never gets old.

reviewText:
Originally, I would not have recommended this game to anyone. When it had launched, the first twenty-four hours the game was practically unplayable for me due to constant screen tearing, flickering, and crashing. I had decided to put the game to the side for a day or so until I figured a fix or something would be out.

Making the decision to put the game down for a bit was a great idea. I say this since the game did a total 180 in quality within those hours. The game went from completely unplayable to a very smooth and enjoyable experience. I'm not sure if a majority of people are having the same experience as me now, but if they are then the game is totally worth it.

At first, I was worried that I had completely wasted my money on this, the same feeling of being burnt when ROME 2 had launched a few years back. While frustrated with the terrible launch, I decided to play other games for a while until a fix was released. Once I had seen that the fix was released and some more time had gone by, I finally got to play and ENJOY Total War: Warhammer and look forward to what the future holds with this game.

EDIT 25/05/16

The day 1 hotfix has greatly reduced the loading times for me. Seems a non issue now.

Initial thoughts on this game -

reviewText: So 5 hours (at the time of review) isn't tonnes of time, but so far it looks like that is going to climb. The game is amazing if it works, now it works fine for me but i heard about someone who had a crash at the start of every campaign. But anyway, to begin with this is a solid Total War game. My experience has been rather good, its got all your expected Total War features but the fantasy setting spices it up a lot giving the game many good new features, such as hereos you can level up and customise (by the way you can rename cities and individual units not just heroes) there are cool new beasties to command including flying ones which work well as far as i have seen as does the magic, the quests are pretty neat too. I recommend this game because it is a good Total War game and all the elements that Warhammer bring in work very well providing a very satifying experience. If you guys get it i wish you luck and hope it works fine. I currently run this on high, the same preset i have on Attila but i find this game running nicer and prettier than Attila did. Good luck guys and to those of you who get this i hope you enjoy what is in my opinion possibly my farvorite Total War title.

reviewText:
the game runs amazingly well for me at 60 fps on my gtx 970 with most settings turned to ultra with a few turned to high like shadows and grass, the setting of the game is amazing and each faction feels unique and different in their play styles. I wish there were more units but i'm sure we will get more via free lc and dlc packs (most important however is the blood dlc that im sure will come out next month following how all other total wars do the blood packs) The large flying monsters and flying beasts as well as magic give the game a unique feeling that is totally different from past total wars. I wish all legendary lords could ride mounts such as Sigvard the Magnificent who is just a human dude who cant even ride a horse for some odd reason and Archeon only gets a little horse when a regular lord can mount a chaos dragon is just odd, something im sure modders will fix so np. Mods for the game are great and already after a few hours of release tons of them are being released that improve on the game. A great addition total war and I cant wait for next years expansions and any upcoming historical total wars CA as in store for us as this has been a great launch for me.

my play time should speak for itself, games been out for 1 day and i have 20 hrs of gameplay, games pretty great cant believe im saying this but i can wait for the incoming dlc

I would also warn those new to the game to not gauge how battles are going based on previous total war games, this game is unique in that it has monsters and magic, a battle that may seem like it will be a sure  win can suddenly turn the other way around if someone shoots a comet in the right place

9/10

(has some minor glitches such as alittle screen flickering when starting campaign and AI aggression is pretty op atm if your chaos but nothing that cant be fixed easily and is overall a great total war experience)

reviewText: Read and don't waste your emperor's time with thumbs down, or I shall show no mercy on you nor your village, as it will burn under my army, its women and children given to the pleasures of my soldiers and then sold to slavery, and its men executed in front of the eyes of their families, then I am Emperor Karl Franz, and I do not tolerate thumbs down.\n\nThe game is as great as it can get. Your armies stand ready to fight, taunting the enemy, under a beautiful scenery of which you can use any part of it, to your advantage (or disadvantage). Send your infantry forward, have your cavalry hiding in a forest, engage your opponents outnumbered 1:3, and when they thought they won, that is when you send your cavalry around their whole army to charge into your enemies back. Watch them react in panic, as they throw down their banners, and flee the battlefield. Watch your infantry laugh at them running away in fear, as your mighty cavalry now charges into the enemies crossbow soldiers. As soon as those soldiers see your horse, they throw down their weapons and flee in panic. You, Lord Reader of this Review, under my guidance and under my command, you shall bring me the head of my enemies, and most importantly, you shall bring me the head of all the leaders of my enemies, as my hall is in dire need of their skulls that shall be turned into my personal drinking cups. Go out there and enjoy fighting against a great AI, face those unpredictable challenges, forge those alliances, squash those abominations, and enjoy being who you were born to be! No, not the emperor because that is me, but a lord commanding my armies.

reviewText:
3 words - Warhammer Total War 8/10 a very good adaption of the tabletop game it is lacking in a few areas but it makes up for them with an almost flawless release, I am not actually sure it was made by The Creative Assembly after this.
For anyone who has played the Total War games it is mostly the same game play with a few nice additions to bring it into a fantasy setting.

Magic is one which works really well doesn't seem overpowered as you can win without it just the same but adds a nice dimension to the game and can turn the tide of battle if used properly.

Hero units these are interesting they take up a slot in your army roster and are the armies general, the legendary lords like The Emperor Karl Franz or Grimgor Ironhide seem to have the power of a whole unit of troops but they are not invincible they can be killed in battle but it doesn't look like you loose them forever they spend around 4 turns unavailable then come back  , you can also recruit random named lords that act as generals and spellcasters and these can die permanently but you can recruit more.

Monstrous units like Giants, Trolls and Vargheist’s (big warewolves) look scary but are easily dealt with using a solid block of infantry like Halberdiers or Dwarf Warriors with great weapons, however they mow through light infantry and cavalry quite quickly so don’t underestimate them.

My favorite faction has to be the Vampire Counts I have not actually played as them but fought many battles against them, their units are quite weak excluding the Black Knights and a few heavy monsters, but the generals and spellcasters are evil, their armys do not break from bad morale as they are dead and fear nothing, instead they start to crumble but still fight just not as effectively, and if you manage to knock out their general the whole army crumbles very quickly barring a few units, they also cause fear and lower the morale of your army.

The Empire are quite interesting to play as, you start of in Reikland with a single city and must fight the secessionists and regain control of the Reikland, after that it is about trying to unit the different states of the Empire together either through conquest, alliances or confederations where you gain full control of their provinces and armies a carry over from Rome Total War and Attila Total War, if you manager to do all this while keeping the Vampires and Greenskins at bay Chaos will re surface and begin invading your lands a few good sized armies invaded my Reik heartlands and even with Karl Franz and a veteran army with magic support I could not hold them off, and in turn lost the game.

I have only seriously played as the Empire and faced the Vampire Counts and other Empire factions in battle so cant describe the other factions of which there are 5 playable Empire, Dwarves, Greenskins, Chaos and Vampire Counts and one not that being Bretonia but I will be playing as all of them as each faction has a unique feel to it from what I have seen in custom battles and seeing them operating on the campaign map.

I would recommend this game to anyone who has played the Total War series and liked them, anyone who plays or has played the Warhammer Fantasy tabletop game back when it was good, check out some gameplay videos on youtube for more in depth details.

It does require a reasonable PC or laptop to play on anything purchased in the last couple of years should run the game on minimum specs, 4gb of RAM and a dual core 3ghz processor will run the game but for best effect get a dedicated Graphics Card with at least 1gb of VRAM to allow for prettier visuals and the like, anyone who has the recommended specs or knows their computers need to take notice of this advice.

reviewText:
Okay, I was going to wait a little while to write the review, but with all the negative reviews about people unable to play it; I figured I better chime in.

If you never played a Total War game let me give you a summary of what to expect. Total War games are a RTS game where you lead huge armies into battle. In campaigns you'll choose a faction and begin managing settlements/cities on an world map. Your goal is to take over the entire campaign map. You can build armies and send them off to fight in the wars you'll start. Now you can choose to auto-resolve the battles or you can command the armies yourself on the battle map. This is where the Total War series shine. On battle maps you'll send units groups to fight the enemy, and you are encourage to use tactics such as flanking, rear attacks, taking the high ground, and etc. to win the battle.

Now onto this latest entry into the franchise:

Total War: Warhammer is the first Total War game to break away from a historical setting and chose to go with a fantasy setting.  But the overall theme of the Total War campaigns is still the same formula; manage cities to get a good economy so that you can build huge armies to take over the campaign map. There are some unique changes depending on which faction you play as. Speaking of factions, this Total War game have got some of the least factions available for the player to use. With past Total War game having around 10 factions, this on only have 3 (4 if you get the preorder/week 1 purchase DLC). But with past Total War game, some of these factions was very similar to each other in play style but in there is none of that in this game. Each faction army rooster come with unique units and there no shared unit between them. So this lead to unique play style and army builds with each factions. At first I was on the fence with the limited number factions, but after seeing how different each are, I think in this case fewer is better.

On the campaign map, one big change Creative Assembly did was make it so that not every settlement on the map could be taken over. Dwarven and Orcish stronghold can't be occupied by the Empire and Vamp Count (and vice versa Orcs and Dwarves can't occupy human settlements). This is the first time Total War have disable the player from taking over the entire map. Now when I first heard this I was worried, especially since armies can take attrition damage as they travel through enemy territories. But you are able to sack them limited them useless to the enemy force them to send an army over there to rebuild the settlement, for a pretty huge fee. It also give you a good amount of loot for doing this. It’s an interesting new mechanic. I’m not saying it bad or good (I haven’t been in a campaign long enough for it make a huge impact on me).

Also another huge feature is magic and lords. Lords serve as general to your armies. Lords generally come in 2 categories: Warrior or Mage. Basically warrior types can take on whole unit with ease, and mage types can cast spells. Lords can tip the scale for fight into your favor. Since they are so powerful, you need to make a judgement of when it worth using them and when to keep them safe. On the campaign map you can level up your lords, and equip them with items and take them on quest to get more items and powerups to make the all the more fearsome on the battle map.

Magic basically is represented in the lower right corner of the battle map and will refill as the battle goes on. Using it at the right time can change the outcome of a fight. On the campaign map there is a feature known as the winds of magic. Basically if the winds are strong, then you’ll have a lot of magic to use on the battle map, but if they are week, you could have none.
I wish I could speak more on how well this game represent Warhammer, but I’ve never played Warhammer before. So I can’t speak on how well it keep to the lore and spirit of the franchise.

Now I’ve only been talking about single player because I haven’t played multiplayer yet. But from what I saw it fairly basic. You got your custom matches, quick battles, and co-op campaigns. With all this new stuff that they added to the single player campaign, I would have expected some new to the multiplayer.

All it all, I found this a refreshing new entry in the Total War franchise. I know many people had technical problems at launch, but the only problem I had was a slight drop in frames. Once I change the setting to high from ultra and I’ve haven’t had an issue since (my specs: i7-4790, GTX 960, 8GB RAM). It’s kind a funny this game run better on my machine than Total War: Rome 2. I’ve had a lot of fun with this game, and can’t wait to playing this some more, especially with all the free DLC that CA announced for this game.

reviewText:
I was playing as the undead counts, growing smart, raiding smart, killing smart.

I became friendlies with the orcs to the south-east of me which were wiping out the dwarves like nothing. This secured that flank. I had two regions fully controlled and fully upgraded, one for units the other for economy. I was making thousands a turn, while having access to all available units and fielding two, then three armies.

So, I'm growing, conquering, destroying. I attack the weak, the ones with only one or two settlements. I ignore the orcs which have a good chunk of the map, and an empire faction which also as a few cities and armies by me.

I make another faction a vessel and let them grow since I start and end wars before they can mobilize. At this point I have 3 full high tier armies, one down south trying to find easy prey to conquer, two in my region keeping me safe.

When bam, chaos comes along. I knew this would happen, but... I didn't realize how bad it would be. Chaos itself has four armies, each moving together, destroying everything. And the barbarian tribes are also moving hard, over a dozen armies between them.

They take my vessels second city, the one they got last turn, and four armies surround their capital the same turn. Over the next two turns I'm martialing my forces, pulling my third army back as fast as I can. My vessels armies get wiped out, but my banshee managed to destroy two full armies by successfully killing the lords leading them. Over the next few turns my vessel gets killed, and I can't help since my two armies would be fighting five armies from the barbarians, and four from chaos.

Suddenly the gods decide to favor me, and the ever chosen is left behind, just out of range of range of the other chaos armies so I pounce, my lord attacks him, he retreats. My second lord attacks him, and together my armies destroy his without losing a single group. Great right? It gets better, the empire, which are friendly with me, get a few confederations and vessels that Same turn, and just in my region have three armies fighting the barbarian tribes.

Next turn... Chaos reacts, two of their lords attack me, and I know if I retreat that will split my two armies apart. So, I fight. Two armies against two, mine have units going from nearly dead to a quarter health missing. I take out their artillery with my air units when their moving their armies to meet, fatal mistake for many of them. My calvalry engages theirs when I tried to flank. My armies are fighting their two lords, each of them flinging dozens of zombies and goals and skeletons a hit. But my armies were keeping their armies back at the same time, bam, the first enemy lord falls to the count leeching life from him in one massive spell. bam the second follows when my count slams into him with his undead flying horse, blade tearing through the massive birds skull. But what? Chaos refuses to give in! And so I battle and battle, doing everything I can to induce as much fear as I can, flanking to destroy moral even further. When their two giants come into the fray. My air units are harassing their units which were split apart, my two lords and my armies are fighting their giants with all they have. No more magic to use to heal or kill, low health on everything with the two giants only a quarter down. Enemy soldiers still coming, refusing to give up and retreat.

I have two air units left, out of the original five, which included an undead dragon, my lords are both nearly dead, my armies are nearky broken, and the enemy still has those damned Giants. It was a loss, my fate had been sealed when their monstrous units entered the fray to help the Giants. But it was a close call, and it was one that bought me just enough time to survive as a faction. I didn't even get besieged.

The empire, my friends, are pushing back the barbarian tribes, and chaos was nice enough to free up some settlements to my north, my fate is not at an end, if anything, this defeat will bring me future glory.

10/10, would die again.

reviewText:
Good gracious, CA finally did a decent release.

The game is well optimized and ran without issues for me. Despite having a rather old PC I can run it on fairly high settings with reliable FPS.

The AI is decent as well, almost beat me in one battle where we had equal number of troops, had to try hard to win it. And that hasn't happened to me in total war since... forever.

That being said, loading times (especially when I first ran the game) were rather long, but they became better afterwards.

If you are fan of Warhammer like I am, get this. You won't be disappointed.

Oh, and... RIDE BRETONNIA!!!

reviewText:
Roughly ~100 turns into Dwarf campaign and few custom battles under belt.

PROS:
- awesome optimization, especially compared to Attila
- solid gameplay, well balanced so far - combat feels fun and impactful
- overall very clear and aesthetically pleasing UI
- fantastic music and sound
- excellent inter/intra faction diversity in all aspects (theme, tech, units, tactics, etc)

CONS:
- some minor graphical glitches (occasional screen stutter)
- some AI armies unit composition could use improvement (entire cav armies), but this is largely personal preference

No other cons worth reporting so far

Would highly recommend the game, very fun departure from usual scope and theme of the TW series.

reviewText:
Edit: newest hotfix managed to fix the loading screen freezeup problem, since I had no further issues with the game beyond that one I can recommend it, but buyer beware some other issues were still not adressed.

--------
My thoughts on this game are mixed.

When it works the game is ridiculously fun. The music is fantastic, the units for the vampire faction which I started with are interesting and the sound design fits the mood (screeches and moans of undead are always so satisfying). AI seems to forgo hillcamping, which is a welcome sight.

The flying / giant units bring some welcome mix into the unit dynamic and the idea of magic being a resource you use on the battle field add some additional twists to the gameplay.

However, I'd hold off on buying it for a few days to see if CA can fix some issues:
-> many people have errors and crashes - supposedly its the server load
-> Vsynch on Nvidia machines causes UI flickering
-> the start screen takes 4 minutes to get past online autenthication to finally open (commonly referred to as the start screen hungup) - this issue has been fixed in the hotfix
-> it seems that some people are starting up on a black screen entirely
-> performance issues on some high end machines. personally haven't encountered them.

reviewText:
*Currently not all hardware is compatible! Watch out!*

I can run this game smoothly my Setup follows. For an actual Gameplay review look lower.

I have a AMD FX 8350 8-Core processor and a GTX 750 Ti so I am slightly below the recommended System requirements regarding the Graphics Card.
I play this game with everything on low except for Texture Quality (High) and Unit Details (High) on a 1600x9000 resolution (since I prefer windowed mode) with 100% Scaling  and
I usually have roughly 50fps even with multiple armies present and in view.
I agree that CA again ♥♥♥♥ed up but since this is a review from my perspective I cannot take the builds of others into account.

*Gameplay part*
I don't know much about the Warhammer universe but surely was interested due to playing some 40k Games.
This game is different from previous Total War games due to the Lords and Heros and of course the Large units. It was confusing to me at first but got the hang of it quickly. The units are intersting and they differ in playstyle a lot.
One large disappointment for me was that units have only few attack animations and because of the new health system they lack fitting death animations.
Other than that it is fun to have a fictional setting for once that is better polished than previous games. Diplomacy was useful to me for the first time ever.

Try to find out if you can run it and get it if you are a fan of such games.

reviewText:
After playing for over 20 hours I'd like to share my impressions with the game and clear some things. Overally game is a lot fun and definitely worth it.

What I like about the game (pros):
+ 5 currently playable races, all have their unique units, lords, tactics,technologies, playstyle,...
To expand on that - for example Greenskins (orcs) don't have flying units, however they have large variety of ground units to make up for it. Enough ranged / melee infantry or even cavalry units.
+ Nice RPG system of levelling your lords / heroes, with equippable items providing another bonuses (weapon, armor,..) and with followers / banners to boost certain abilities. They also randomly get new traits, some are positive (aggresor), some are neutral (blind) and some are negative (dwarf lover)
+ Story and quests both seem interesting
+ Combat looks absolutely amazing, seeing your spider riders ran over enemy archers is one of the best sights you can have.

The things I don't enjoy (cons):
- 'Scummy' AI as forum would say. They like to walk AROUND you, NOT engage a fight unless they have a big advantage and then proceed to sack and run before you can engage them. Sacking your settlement then changing to march to get as far as possible isn't exactly fun.
- Difficulty jumps - if you are a new player, you will enjoy easy difficulty for some time but then you will want a bigger challenge than enemies forever waiting for you to destroy them. Normal on the other hand? 10th turn 2 enemy armies both with 20 units each on a journey to screw you over.
- No Blood & Gore DLC yet (just a minor thing but it'd make the game so much more satisfying)
- If you played other Total War games, you will notice there aren't formations in this one. I don't personally mind it as I am a casual strategy player, but for some it can be a flaw.

The things people like to talk about:
* Artillery is way too accurate - not true. From what I've played artillery has big aoe where it shoots (you can see it when you order an attack), sometimes it misses, sometimes it hits. The radius of it is most likely based on the distance.
* Just 4 races" - There are 5 if you bought it already (counting Chaos) and all races are unique. It's not really 99% the same thing with a minor bonus to a unit type.
* "Lords are way too strong" - yes and no
date: Lords are strong however if you manage to bring them down
recommended: you can easily win a fight where you are outnumbered because the enemy's leadership will significantly drop. IMO they are strong enough to warrant their upkeep"

reviewText:
I'm a passionate model painter and gamer as well as loving the Total War games since Rome. It's a perfect combination for me!

Factions behave so differently it is like playing a different game with each one, rather than just a re-skin with earlier games. Monsters like dragons and giants really add a lot to the battles to make them more exciting. More races will be added as DLC and I imagine, based on the current game, that will add a lot of replayability.

There are some things missing from previous games, like unit formations (wedges for cavalry!) Also, although the factions are very different from each other, there aren't that many in the core game... see DLC

There are a few bugs that need ironing out but when aren't there with a Total War game! If you are really into Warhammer and Total War then get it, although my advice is to give it a few months for it to be patched up.

reviewText:
THE EFFORT ROME 2 SHOULD HAVE HAD!!

Total War fan since Rome 1 (still my all time favorite). This game is incredible.

VOICE ACTING: Fantastic. Rome 2's voice acting was horrid, this is an absolute 180 degree turn. The intro speeches, battles and campaign map are superb.

MUSIC: BRING BACK JEFF VAN DYCK! That said I'm really enjoying the musical score of this game.

PERFORMANCE: GTX 970
8 GB ram
i5-4670K Oc'd to 4.0
Had a 55 unit battle, no slowdown on max graphics, minus V-sync and blur. Performance is outstanding.

ATMOSPHERE: Really sucks you in. Levelling up your hero's and lord's, magic abilities are great fun.

GRAPHICS: Awesome. Some people dislike the lack of 1v1 fights between units but I think it looks way better. Less blobbing, and charges look solid.

Sorry for the rushed review, but this is the first game in awhile that I really want to get back to playing. Buy it.
