reviewText:
Rocky start for some multiplayer issues, some minor issues with NVIDIA users (Playing in Windowed to have no screen tearing, and alt tabbing in and back out will solve the black tearing in the cinematic / menu mess ups for most users, IF YOU ARE CRASHING PUT STEAM IN OFFLINE MODE)

It did have some minor performance issues that seem to not like NVIDIA cards in general judging by posts on reddit and performance issues. As for the game, the factions seem varied, battles feel great, units feel like they have weight to them.(Don't equip your melee lord with a horse and run him into battle first *COUGH*) Flanking with horses works really well. So far i've only scratched the surface of the Empire Campaign. There is plenty of streamers / reviews with videos out there so look those up if you having trouble on deciding to purchase or not.

Their team is working really hard to get patches out with problems and hotfixes so enjoy the game and WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGH!!

reviewText:
Amazing game. Performance is much better compared to Attila which was really horrible for me. The races feel very different from each other and unique though some time I still wish there were more factions, like the Elves etc for even more variety.

I love the inclusion of leaders and heroes, as well as magic, they really change the feel of traditional TW games as you can control one single mighty unit to wreck havoc in a sea of one thousand soldiers.

And it's also great that Sega allowed modding for the game after all. So I would recommend a buy ASAP to get the Chaos faction for free.

A must-buy for total war and warhammer fans, and a very good introduction for people interested in the series.

reviewText:
I'll admit, I was dubious. Long time player of Total War, since the original Shogun and while I no longer play the tabletop games of Games Workshop I hugely enjoy the ridiculousness of the lore and setting.

With recent Games Workshop games often being so poor (Though there are exceptions) and having the debacle that was Rome 2 put me off the franchise enough to not even bother with Atila, if you'd asked me a while ago whether I was looking forward to this game the answer would have be no. I wasn't interested.

What ended up changing that opinion however, was a hands on playing both as the Empire vs Vampire Counts and Vampire Counts against Orcs at Rezzed. They were both set custom battles, but they demonstrated to me just how much effort was being put in to make the factions unique and different instead of just reskinned.

Now, after playing nearly 24 hours of the final release I'm quite happy to say that it feels like the game is nicely optimized and mostly bug free though they need to do some work with Nvidia to work with their cards (Not that I'm suffering any graphical glitches. Running on a 980 gtx. I did see some oddities with V-sync enabled. Turned it off, and they went away. Not suffering due to it. Game looks beautiful). The factions, are utterly unique and play differently and just I can't express how much I've been enjoying it. It feels a lot more streamlined in terms of the building/politics in comparison to previous TWs but at the same time I almost feel like it helps the experience. It's a lot more aggressive, as fitting the universe, and this game has actually helped rekindle quite a lot of my faith in CA.

I can only hope that future DLC is of the same standard, and done decently such as the fact Chaos Warriors are free for this first week, not just on preorder. If you're on the fence about it, I'd say jump in. Give it a try. It is a LOT of fun.

reviewText:
How CA got their Groove Back.

After the dissapointing release of Rome 2 and the only slightly better Attila we had reason to be aprehensive.
However, I'm pleased to report that TWW is fantastic and the one of the best entries in the entire series.
I understand that some people had performance or startup issues on day one but the game has worked smoothly for me on a VERY budget PC. No lag, crashes or serious bugs except for one crash in a MP game in 40+ hours of gameplay. This is probably the best optomized TW release we've ever had and kudos to CA for that.

Pros -

Really captures the essence of the world and is very immersive.
The graphics, sound and music are all great.
Battle and Campaign AI are vastly improved.
Colorful and detailed UI.
Varied factions with vastly different and interesting play styles.
Role playing elements are awesome and it's great fun developing your characters.
Turn times are very quick, probably a quarter or less of the length of Rome 2 or Attila.
I can build walls again! Thank you CA.

Cons -

MP is underdeveloped, no custom armies, conquest, or really any of the features that were in Shogun 2.
No custom painting for armies (Would have been nice for tabletop fans or for MP armies).
As of the current build AI heroes are too OP and will slay your level 20 general over and over again.

I'm a bonafide Rome 2 hater and I love this game.

It will satisfy any long neglected TW itch you may have.

Now back to the badlands, WAAAAAAAAGGHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!

reviewText:
Hello everyone :) Today I will be tring to give a full honest review of TW: W

The Good
Performance:  First off let me say that my computer is good but it definetly isn't the best. So when I booted this up I expected mabye 40 FPS on high. What I got though was around 50-60 fps on ultra.

Campaign:  The campaign is great, you truly feel that every race is uniqe and they all play quite differently. As someone who usually played legendary on other TW games this one provided a new challenge to me and I had to bump it down to hard after my first few attempts as the greenskins.

Large Units/Magic:  These guys are amazing. It feels incredible to send in a giant spider as your line is crumbling or using your hero's flame spiral to destroy theirs. You can really feel they power of each spell, or eachstomp as they tear into the enemy.

Battle:  The battles in TW W absolutely stun me. From towering giants to shambling zombies I feel like the devs had a dream, and they fulfilled that dream. Everything feels so well balanced and the units look amazing.

Lords:  Having quests and skill trees is really great. It makes everything feel very open ended and allows large amounts of replayability.

The Bad
Bugs:  Playing through the game your going to find bugs. Lots of them. Most of these will be fixed within a few weeks but it must be included. So far I haven't found any gamebreaking bugs but that doesn't mean they aren't there.

Performance (Again):  As said previously I have great performance. However loads of people are saying that they get terrible FPS so make sure to look into whether or not your comp can run it.

Multiplayer  If its possible I think that the MP might have gotten worse since Attila. There are less options (Time of day, attacker direction, world map) and it crashes occasionally.

And The Misc  Arcade  Now, I'm not saying that this is a bad thing, but it must be included that the battles are much faster then in any previous TW game.

Economy  Since Attila all aspects like food/sanitation have been removed. Personally I hated the way Attila handled it but for those who like managing cities I just wanted to let you know.

Do you guys think I covered everything well? If not leave a comment and I will include it in the review.

reviewText:
After sinking many hours into all Total War games over a period of years, I think it's safe to say I was rather excited to see this come out. Though the recent installments in the TW series have left a sour taste in my mouth (Rome 2 and Attila to be exact) I remained hopeful that this would hark back to TW roots, and was not disappointed.

The factions are all vasty different, offering completely unique and diverse units to play around with. The mechanics that each faction have are different, ensuring that no play through shall ever be the same as another. While I dislike some of the mechanics (Orc Waaagh! for one) that is only down person playstyle.

The game itself is graphically beautiful, from campaign to battle map and unit models. Loading the AI turns, something that Rome 2 took way too long to do and Attila was awful for, is now almost instantaneous and back to Medieval 2's precedent. The fact that your heroes or Lords" have a vast array of gear and options to take while levelling up can really change the tide of a battle
date: which I enjoy a lot more than a simple King/General with randomly generated stats and talents.\n\nOverall
recommended: I really feel this is a step in the right direction for the TW series and shows that they are able to step away from the historical based games and into fantasy very seamlessly
hoursPlayed: incorporating the new universe while keeping true to the game series' core mechanics. Very
voteText: very pleased."

reviewText:
Okay, nearly twenty hours of play, two Short Campaign beatdown for Orkz and Vampires and one Long Campaign victory for Empire now done, I can confidently say that I can indeed review this game as is now.

First Looks:
Alright, first off, this game is ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful. It really captures the whole over-blinged competency feel Fantasy and 40K have for themselves. (i.e. the more bling, the more badass your hero is.)

Then we have the combat. Typical Total War, though oddly lacking formations like previous titles, such as Phalanx, Shield Wall and Wedge. But they added mod support, so I'll wait for an awesome modder to try and implement that. Kill animations are still great and the blood is decent. (DLC for that will come and I'll buy that on sale). Also seemingly lacks city and town fights. Really sad.

Diplomacy. It's actually a whole lot better than in previous titles, which is great. Much easier to just slowly build your forces and economy, so once Chaos starts invading, EVERYONE is willing to put aside petty differences and join the Empire to fight the invasion. Not sure how it works for other factions, but I'll see later.

Building and Economy. Not as indepth as Rome, Medieval and Shogun, about the same as Rome 2 and Attila. Everything has its place and if you want an economy churning out 10K gold and hundreds of soldiers each turn, you need to invest smartly.

Leaders and Heroes. Great looking Legendary Heroes that only get 'wounded' when assassinated and much squishier, yet oh so awesome regular Heroes are found here. Legendary Heroes are the faction leaders and the side-characters. They're a little bit stronger than Heroes, but not OP. I've taken down each faction leader in direct mano-a-mano combat with a Hero of equal level. It all comes down to Skills, Items and Vassals. Correctly choosing the right stuff is something you have to pick up on; no guide yet. Heroes are more numerous and can make or break a battle. Either by slowing the army down or assassinating/wounding the leader on the World Map or taking to the field on the Battle Map, a Hero decides how a battle will be lost.

Overall, its great so far, but we'll see how things go in the coming months.

PROS so far:
-Fantasy fans will appreciate the game. Too little Fantasy and too much 40K recently.
-Factions are well done, plus free CHAOS DLC for preorders are great.
-Unit models look great on even low settings.
-Campaigns are just as great as previous titles but also have sidequests to gain awesome gear.
-RPG-elements better integrated than previous titles.
-Mod support
-Mods already available, minutes after launch
-Diplomacy done better, likely inspiration from modders of previous titles

CONS so far:
-Unit models aren't very diverse
-AI Agents have higher success rate than player, as usual
-Not bloody enough for a Warhammer title.
-Not enough Hero diversity; same models with very simple variations.
-No battle formations or tactics implemented, sadly.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is exactly what it's called. It's a Total War game that has Warhammer in it.

So you've got magic units, a bit more customizability for agents/generals than in past titles, and they've added some flavor quests and faction specific mechanics to tie the game more closely to the setting. None of these things are bad, none of these dramatically shake up the genre or set a new benchmark for similar games, but TW: Warhammer is a fun TW game that is mostly evolutionary in nature.

Overall I'd recommend it if you like the TW franchise.

That said, I have similar gripes about this one as previous installments:
1. Even though it can take awhile to move around and such, the map still feels" small. I always feel like things are a bit too scaled up. It doesn't really detract from gameplay
date: there is certainly a fair amount to do and every playthrough ends up being a bit different
recommended:
but the feeling is always there nagging at me.

2. So many locked factions.

3. Empire management is simple and mostly just flavor between each of your battles. Given that Atilla and Rome 2 both had a bit deeper management layer (for some factions)
hoursPlayed: it's kinda sad to see it simplified back down again. That said
voteText: if you mostly just want to play the battles
helpfulPercent: which are usually the high point of these games
votesHelpful: this might not be that big a deal for you."

reviewText:
Cracking game. Played a solid 40 hours doing both the vampire and dwarf campaigns and it's a great game.

- Smooth Graphics, looks great
- No crashes, bugs or hiccups

voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
How CA got their Groove Back.

After the dissapointing release of Rome 2 and the only slightly better Attila we had reason to be aprehensive.
However, I'm pleased to report that TWW is fantastic and the one of the best entries in the entire series.
I understand that some people had performance or startup issues on day one but the game has worked smoothly for me on a VERY budget PC. No lag, crashes or serious bugs except for one crash in a MP game in 40+ hours of gameplay. This is probably the best optomized TW release we've ever had and kudos to CA for that.

Pros -

Really captures the essence of the world and is very immersive.
The graphics, sound and music are all great.
Battle and Campaign AI are vastly improved.
Colorful and detailed UI.
Varied factions with vastly different and interesting play styles.
Role playing elements are awesome and it's great fun developing your characters.
Turn times are very quick, probably a quarter or less of the length of Rome 2 or Attila.
I can build walls again! Thank you CA.

Cons -

MP is underdeveloped, no custom armies, conquest, or really any of the features that were in Shogun 2.
No custom painting for armies (Would have been nice for tabletop fans or for MP armies).
As of the current build AI heroes are too OP and will slay your level 20 general over and over again.

I'm a bonafide Rome 2 hater and I love this game.

It will satisfy any long neglected TW itch you may have.

Now back to the badlands, WAAAAAAAAGGHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Total War: Warhammer
Always been a big fan og the TW series. So this really reflects my review since i compare it to previous TW gameplay.
This is what Total War is great for, this kind of gameplay and the right kind of universe!

I tried first greenskins but got kicked back and fourth before finaly everything i had buildt had crumbled and Dwarfs rushed my capital" and yelled GG! I still had a blast even tough i lost hard.

I really loved the way texts are writtin in funny Orcish warhammer style. The "story" felt compeling and good the little i saw of it before getting destroyed.

The second game i started was with The Empire! Now this felt easier to play. Having a hell of a time. And just having a blast trying out Hero skills and learning the faction. Units feels great and balanced and everyone having a place in the game and not randomly placed there to fill unit slots.

9/10
"

reviewText:
A step in the right direction for the Total War series.

Pros

-Diverse cultures to play as (orcs, Dwarfes, Humans ext)
-Diverse Game play
-Good starting mods
-Amazing battles
-Great graphics
-Cav charges
-Monsters

Cons

-Although the cultures are different from other cultures, the factions within those cultures that you fight against are exactly the same.
-Chaos Warriors DLC
-Low diversity in human infantry (there are like 4)
-Simplified campaign map
-Overcomplicated quest battles

To be real, most of the cons are not that big of a deal. Only one really matters (from a game play perspective). Its the copy paste factions. If you play play the Empire every other human faction besides Brettonia has your exact same units. Its the same for every culture to. They don't even bother with the names sometimes, it still calls them Empires swordsman. You spend the first half of the game fighting armies that are completely the same, and then you get to the good stuff. Once you get there though, the battles are amazing. Just a little more effort in some of the factions and I would have legit no complaints about this game.

reviewText:
I'll admit, I was dubious. Long time player of Total War, since the original Shogun and while I no longer play the tabletop games of Games Workshop I hugely enjoy the ridiculousness of the lore and setting.

With recent Games Workshop games often being so poor (Though there are exceptions) and having the debacle that was Rome 2 put me off the franchise enough to not even bother with Atila, if you'd asked me a while ago whether I was looking forward to this game the answer would have be no. I wasn't interested.

What ended up changing that opinion however, was a hands on playing both as the Empire vs Vampire Counts and Vampire Counts against Orcs at Rezzed. They were both set custom battles, but they demonstrated to me just how much effort was being put in to make the factions unique and different instead of just reskinned.

Now, after playing nearly 24 hours of the final release I'm quite happy to say that it feels like the game is nicely optimized and mostly bug free though they need to do some work with Nvidia to work with their cards (Not that I'm suffering any graphical glitches. Running on a 980 gtx. I did see some oddities with V-sync enabled. Turned it off, and they went away. Not suffering due to it. Game looks beautiful). The factions, are utterly unique and play differently and just I can't express how much I've been enjoying it. It feels a lot more streamlined in terms of the building/politics in comparison to previous TWs but at the same time I almost feel like it helps the experience. It's a lot more aggressive, as fitting the universe, and this game has actually helped rekindle quite a lot of my faith in CA.

I can only hope that future DLC is of the same standard, and done decently such as the fact Chaos Warriors are free for this first week, not just on preorder. If you're on the fence about it, I'd say jump in. Give it a try. It is a LOT of fun.

reviewText:
First playthrough (Empire) - Look at all the armies! How does diplomacy work again? I wonder what all these improvements do. Which units to build? Well, I only have two cities, but...hey, wait...why are all those Stirland troops pouring across my borders? Are we at war?

Second playthough (Dwarves) - Beards! Beards everywhere! Prosporous little buggers, tho. Lots of ranged, which is pretty neat, and the gyrocoptors look...hey...are those orcs?

Third playthrough (Vampires) - Well, I seem to finally have a handle on this. I have two whole provinces under control, a half dozen heroes, three armies with two legendary lords, a bunch of late stage units, and the #1 ranking for military in the game. I've got the Empire down to just one city! To my south, nothing but sparkling, dwarf-free mountains! I think this'll be the one where I finally...hey, what the hell is up with that giant centaur thing? Is that...is that Chaos? Oh G-d, are multiple Chaos hordes crossing my northern border?

Anyway, it's pretty cool.

reviewText: The best total war game hands down. As a hardcore fan of the series the only question i\'m asking myself is why the heck didn\'t this come sooner? It\'s a beautiful game, and challengingly fun that leaves you with a sense of accomplishment. It\'s got a deep lore rich background and wonderfully constructed gameplay. Althought there are currently 5 official playable races at the moment each one is fleshed out and polished to a silver gleam, each one is very different and unique. reviewText:
Total War: Warhammer, oh boy.

Being honest here, i know very little about Warhammer fantasy(40K fanboy), but even so this game amazes me, so here's what's up.

There so far in total 5 playable races (1 including DLC), With each race possessing different play styles and mechanics, Each race has two differant starting legendary lords( 3 for DLC race), being pretty much over glorified generals. like previous Total War titles, All your generals gain experience through things like battle. What's new is that you are able to personalise them, obtaining mounts for them, items through quests and battles, bestowing titles unto them (only as The Empire Race), obtaining all kinds of banners and retainers of the like. Lords are important, as they are needed to muster your forces, and their abilties and even spells can be key to winning battle. Agents/Heroes Are also very important, if not more so now. In previous games, they were used for assasinations, spying, bullying armies, sabotage you name it. Now along with all that, they can also act as secondary lords in armies, with many sharing the same abilities of lords, they become very valuable. In Warhammer, lords are now a single but powerful units, with enough power to even slay monsters if strong enough.

Monsters can vary in many different ways. There are single large powerful creatures able to kill a few men in one swipe. There are flying bats, armoured trolls, DRAGON OGRES??, Normal (sort of) dragons, poisonous hounds and even sp00ky ghosts.

Total War: Warhammer brings Warhammer fantasy into the our beloved total war, but just how much total war have they taken out and filled with fantasy? well.
-While combat is really fun to take part of and is amazing to watch, it is also quite bland, your units have almost little to none abilties, or even lack any combat formation. No fire arrows, no Shield walls, no Phalanx, no Square Formation, Nothing.
-No Kill moves
-no proper tax control (since rome 2)
-no ones eats in warhammer fantasy??
-Races are restricted to occupying only members of the same race and their immediate opposing factions such as, empire and vampires and orcs and dwarves (chaos being a horde races)
-Vampires literally have no ranged units, and Chaos hardly show any.
-The empire seem to be a powerhouse yielding most unit types (so much siege as well), making it seem unbalanced for other races.
-Literally No Navel.
-few races lack diplomatic options

However that doesn't mean this is a bad game, for what seems to be so many things missing in this game, there's a lot that makes up for it.
-The Rpg element into lords and heroes.
-MAGIC
-The graphics are nice with optimization being okay done, furthure updates hopefully fix for others
-Each race has various things that are unique to them, such as the Orc's Waaagghh, the vampires ability to raise the dead and even corrupt nearby provinces(also with Chaos).
-The quest battles are exciting for legendary lords and also rewarding.
-voices are nicely done
-design gone into the units and even especially that of the lords and bigger creatures are very pleasing.
-The Ai have definiately stepped up their game, a much bigger improvement from previous titles (although diplomacy can vary, but still).
-siege is less messy and all over the places, more simplified
-nice introduction for the normal factions, making it easier on new players.
-units are much easier to understand, making it easier to use them.
-Mod Support

Thank you Creative Assembly.
Thank you Sega.
Keep up the good work.
